questions.text:
A 50-year-old female presents with a 4 x 3 cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, which is not fixed to the skin or the chest wall. A 2 cm lymph node is palpated in the right axilla. No mass is noted in the opposite breast. Which of the following investigations would you perform in this patient?


	Bilateral Mammography
	PET Scan
	Biopsy of the breast mass
	USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1 & 3

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate course of action in this case is to first perform mammography, followed by a biopsy of the breast mass to confirm whether it is malignant.
  • Mammography:
    • It is the gold standard for evaluating suspicious breast masses.
    • In this case, it helps assess the mass’s characteristics (e.g., shape, edges, density) and detect any other lesions in the contralateral breast, which is important given the patient's age and increased breast cancer risk.
  • Biopsy of the breast mass:
    • It is crucial to determine if the mass is malignant or benign (FNA or core needle).
    • It provides tissue for histopathological examination, which guides treatment decisions based on tumour type, grade, and receptor status.
  • Triple assessment is a combination of assessments used for breast cancer screening and diagnosis.

Triple Assessment of Breast Examination

1. Clinical Examination

Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy.

Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes.

2. Imaging

Methods:

  • Mammography: Preferred for women over 40.
  • Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation.

3. Biopsy

Types:

  • FNA: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions.
  • Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses.
  • Excisional: Removes lump for examination.

Triple assessment yields more accurate results than individual assessment.


PET Scan (Statement 2) is generally used for staging or detecting distant metastasis after a diagnosis of breast cancer is confirmed. It is not normally employed in the initial workup of a palpable breast mass.

USG-guided biopsy of the lymph node (Statement 4) is not done in cases of clinically palpable axillary nodes.

questions.text: The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Reverse Trendelenburg position

Explanation:

  • The position of the patient shown in the image is known as the Reverse Trendelenburg position.
  • The patient is placed with the head elevated above the level of the head and the feet lowered than the head.
  • This position is often used during upper abdominal surgeries.

Positioning on the Operating Table

Position

Description

Uses and Complications

Supine Position

Most common position for general surgical procedures.

Modifications of Supine position:

  • Rose’s position
  • Shoulder and Arm Extended
  • Trendelenburg Position
  • Reverse Trendelenburg Position
  • Fowler's Position

General surgeries.

 

Rose's Position

Supine with slight neck extension.

Head and neck surgery.

Shoulder and Arm Extended

Supine with shoulder and arm extended.

Axillary and breast surgery.

Trendelenburg Position

(Option C)

Head end tilted down, knees slightly flexed.

Pelvic procedures, resuscitating patients in shock.

Reverse Trendelenburg Position

The head end tilted upward, placing the head higher than the feet.

Upper abdominal surgeries.

Complication: Right shoulder pain due to CO2 collected under the right dome of the diaphragm during laparoscopic cholecystectomy

 

Fowler's Position

Semi-sitting with the trunk raised at 40° and knees bent.

Neurosurgery, shoulder surgeries, patients with heart or respiratory failure.

Complication: Increased risk of air embolism.

Prone Position

The patient is intubated and log-rolled onto the operating bed with help.

Spinal surgery, extra levator abdominoperineal excision for rectal cancer.

Jackknife Position

(Option B)

(Prone Position Modification)

Chest supported, abdomen relaxed by flexing at the hips.

Provides excellent access to the perineum.

Complication: Positional asphyxia

Lateral Decubitus or Kidney Position

Lower leg flexed, pillow between legs, upper leg flexed in an exaggerated position.

Draining abscesses, lateral thoracotomy, urological and retroperitoneal procedures.

Complication: Increased risk of brachial plexus injury due to hyperextension

Lithotomy Position

Supine with hips and knees flexed, legs in stirrups, hips flexed to 90°.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

Complication: Common peroneal nerve injury if legs are not supported properly

Lloyd-Davies Position

(Option A)

(Lithotomy Modification)

Supine with hips minimally flexed (~15°) and a 30° head-down tilt.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is correct?

1. Autosomal dominant disease

2. Defect in the STK11 gene

3. Melanin spots on digits and perianal skin

4. Autosomal recessive

5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome :

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by a loss of function mutation in the STK11 gene (statements 1 & 2) (statement 4 ruled out)
  • It presents around 11 years of age.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic but may present with chronic bleeding, anaemia, or intussusception.
  • Histology: An arborising pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium.
  • It is characterised by:
    • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, perianal region and extremities) (statement 3)
  • Polyps are large, pedunculated, and lobulated.
  • Significant risk of cancers:
    • Small bowel, colon, pancreas, lungs, testis, ovaries, breast, and endometrium
    • Lifetime cancer risk is estimated at 40%

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain. On examination, his HR is 110 bpm, BP-88/60 mmHg. Guarding is present on per abdomen examination. Erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would you proceed with for the management of this case?

A. USG abdomen

B. IV fluids

C. Exploratory laparotomy

D. Elective surgery

E. Conservative management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B & C

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation, along with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) visible on the erect abdominal X-ray, strongly suggests the perforation of a hollow organ.
  • The most appropriate management for this patient, who likely has a gastrointestinal perforation, is to administer IV fluids to stabilise the patient and then proceed with exploratory laparotomy for immediate surgical intervention.
  • Elective surgery is not appropriate for a patient with an acute perforation as it is an emergency, and delaying surgery for an elective procedure would be harmful. (Statement D ruled out)
  • Imaging is already done (X-ray showing free air), so no further imaging (like ultrasound) is required immediately, and conservative management would not be effective or appropriate in this emergency situation. (Statement A & E ruled out)

Pneumoperitoneum

  • Causes:
    • Common: Perforated peptic ulcers, bowel obstruction, inflammatory conditions, ischemia, injury during colonoscopy.
    • Other causes without peritonitis: Postoperative (up to 7 days), peritoneal dialysis, sealed perforation, and tracking from pneumomediastinum.
  • Diagnosis on Imaging:
    • Erect CXR: Free gas is seen under the right hemidiaphragm (cupola sign), but it is difficult to differentiate on the left due to gastric or colonic gas.
    • Supine AXR: Right upper quadrant gas in the perihepatic, subhepatic space, Morrison’s pouch, and ligament visualisation (e.g., falciform ligament).
    • Rigler’s Sign: Visualization of both sides of the bowel wall due to surrounding gas.
    • CT Scan: Most sensitive; small volumes of gas seen in the liver or peritoneal recesses, often using broad window settings.
  • Management: is surgical, i.e., Exploratory laparotomy + Peritoneal lavage + Repair of perforation.

questions.text: Except for which of the following, the concentration of all the following decreases as the filtrate passes through the proximal convoluted tubule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chloride

Explanation:

  • Chloride (Cl-) is passively reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) through the paracellular pathway, following sodium reabsorption.
  • Unlike glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate, chloride is not actively reabsorbed and its concentration does not decrease as significantly.

As the filtrate passes through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), various substances are reabsorbed into the bloodstream:

Substance

Reabsorption mechanism

Concentration change in PCT

Glucose

Actively reabsorbed via sodium-glucose co-transporters

Decreases significantly

(Option B ruled out)

Amino acids

Actively reabsorbed via sodium-amino acid co-transporters

Decreases significantly

(Option A ruled out)

Bicarbonate

Reabsorbed via sodium-hydrogen exchanger and sodium-bicarbonate co-transporter

Decreases significantly

(Option D ruled out)

Chloride

Passively reabsorbed, relatively impermeable in early PCT

Does not decrease significantly, may increase

questions.text: Identify the following correctly.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Left inguinal hernia

Explanation:

  • An image of swelling in the left inguinal region is given, which suggests a left inguinal hernia. (Option B ruled out)
  • Inguinal Hernia is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia).

Feature

Indirect Inguinal Hernia

Direct Inguinal Hernia

Common in

Young adults

Elderly

Course

It enters through the deep inguinal ring, traverses the inguinal canal, and exits via the superficial inguinal ring.

Protrudes directly through Hesselbach's triangle

Relation to Spermatic Cord

Anterolateral to the spermatic cord

Posterior to the spermatic cord

Location of Neck of Sac

Above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Lies within the Hesselbach's triangle.

Relation to Inferior Epigastric vessels

Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Relation to Scrotum

Descends into the scrotum

Does not Descend

Types
  • Bubonocele: Confined to inguinal canal
  • Funicular: Processus vaginalis closed above epididymis, hernia content distinct from testis
  • Complete/Scrotal: Testis in the lower part of the hernia

 

 

—

CA bladder (Option A) generally causes symptoms like hematuria, increased frequency, or painful urination, but it would not normally present with bulging in the inguinal area.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a slow-growing, rubbery, non-tender swelling on the side of the neck, as shown in the image. Examination shows the presence of freckles and light skin patches over the face and trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neural tumour

Explanation:

  • The presence of freckles, light skin patches, and a rubbery swelling in the neck in this 15-year-old boy strongly points to neural tumours.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a genetic disorder that often presents with freckling in the axillary (called Crowe's sign) or inguinal areas and café-au-lait spots (the skin patches). These skin findings are characteristic of the disorder.
  • Neurofibromas, are benign neural tumours that arise from the nerve sheath and commonly appear as soft, rubbery, non-tender swellings in affected areas like the neck.

 

Cystic hygroma (Option A) is a type of cavernous haemangioma, present since the time of birth, which is benign and grows rapidly in years, often over the neck or axilla. It is not associated with freckles or café-au-lait spots.

Chemodectoma (Option B) (Paragangliomas) arise from paraganglia, which are clusters of neuroendocrine cells located in various parts of the body. They are commonly found in the head and neck regions. Freckles and skin patches are not typically associated with them but rather with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Lipomas (Option D) are benign fatty tumours that can occur in various body parts, including the neck. They are usually soft, movable, and painless, but they do not present with freckles or café-au-lait spots.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Parathyroid adenoma

Explanation:

  • A parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism, where the parathyroid gland itself produces excess parathyroid hormone (PTH). This is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Incorrect Options:

Lithium intake (Option B): Chronic lithium use interferes with calcium sensing in the parathyroid glands, leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Vitamin D deficiency (Option C): Impairs calcium absorption, leading to low calcium levels. This stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more PTH to increase calcium levels, resulting in secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Chronic kidney disease (Option D): Reduces the kidneys' ability to excrete phosphate and activate vitamin D, disrupting calcium and phosphate balance, which leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction?

1. Extracellular Ca2+ is not essential for contraction

2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria

3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 and 3

Explanation:

  • Extracellular Ca2+ is not essential for skeletal muscle contraction as calcium primarily comes from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR).
  • The release of Ca2+ from the SR is crucial for muscle contraction, while voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on the sarcolemma play a role in excitation-contraction coupling.

Sequential events during muscle contraction

Release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

An action potential triggers the release of calcium ions (Ca²⁺) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm of the muscle cell. (Statement 2 ruled out)

Binding of calcium ions to troponin C

Calcium ions bind to troponin C on the thin filaments, causing a conformational change in the troponin complex.

Cross-bridge formation between myosin and actin

The conformational change in the troponin complex moves tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin, allowing the myosin heads (with ADP and Pi bound) to attach to the exposed binding sites on actin.

Power stroke, moving the myosin head from 90 degrees to 45 degrees

The myosin head pivots from a 90-degree angle to a 45-degree angle, pulling the actin filament toward the center of the sarcomere. ADP and Pi are released during this movement.

Detachment of the myosin head from actin

A new ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament.

Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi, re-cocking the myosin head

The ATP is hydrolyzed to ADP and Pi, providing energy to re-cock the myosin head back to the 90-degree position, ready for another cycle of contraction.

 

(Statement 4 ruled out)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg, and his pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased, resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Arterial wall compliance

Explanation:

  • Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure. It is inversely proportional to the compliance of the arteries.
  • When arterial compliance decreases (as in aging or atherosclerosis), arteries become stiffer and less able to expand.
  • This leads to a larger increase in systolic pressure, resulting in a higher pulse pressure. The arteries cannot absorb the pressure variation as effectively, causing the systolic pressure to rise more, and consequently, the pulse pressure increases.

Incorrect Options:

Myocardial contractility (Option A): While myocardial contractility affects stroke volume, it does not directly affect pulse pressure in the way arterial compliance does.

Stroke volume (Option B): Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume; however, a decrease in stroke volume would typically decrease pulse pressure, not increase it.

Cardiac output (Option D): Affects pulse pressure indirectly through its impact on stroke volume, but the primary factor in this case is decreased arterial compliance.

questions.text: What is the underlying mechanism of action for pain reduction by transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gate Control Theory

Explanation:

  • The Gate control theory, developed by Patrick Wall and Ronald Melzack, explains that pain perception is modulated by the interaction between different nerve fibers in the spinal cord.
    • Large-diameter Aα and Aβ fibers inhibit the transmission of pain signals from small-diameter C fibers in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord by activating inhibitory interneurons, effectively "closing the gate" to pain.
    • TENS works by stimulating these large-diameter fibers, reducing pain perception through this mechanism.

Incorrect Options:

Central inhibition (Option A): Refers to the reduction of pain processing at the central nervous system level, but TENS primarily works via spinal cord modulation (gate control), not central inhibition.

Desensitization (Option B): Involves the reduction in the sensitivity of pain receptors over time, but is not the primary mechanism of TENS.

Descending inhibition (Option D): Involves pain inhibition through descending pathways from the brain, which is a different mechanism from gate control.

questions.text: A neuron receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons can be best described as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Convergence

Explanation:

  • Convergence refers to a situation where multiple presynaptic neurons (in this case, 150 sensory neurons) send signals to a single postsynaptic neuron.
  • This leads to the summation of inputs, allowing the postsynaptic neuron to integrate and respond to multiple inputs.
  • In this clinical scenario, the neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons, which fits the definition of convergence.

Incorrect Options:

Divergence (Option A): Occurs when one neuron sends its output to multiple neurons, not the other way around.

Feedback inhibition (Option C): This refers to a regulatory mechanism where the output of a neuron inhibits its own activity or the activity of upstream neurons

Feedforward system (Option D): This refers to a mechanism where a neuron sends signals that facilitate or prepare for a future action, often without the influence of previous outputs

questions.text: How do eukaryotes engage in intercellular communication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Exosome

Explanation:

  • Exosomes are nano-sized extracellular vesicles secreted by eukaryotic cells that play a significant role in intercellular communication.
  • They carry various molecules, including proteins, lipids, and RNA, from one cell to another, facilitating communication and influencing various physiological and pathological processes.
  • Exosomes can transfer their cargo to recipient cells, thereby modulating their function.

Incorrect Options:

Lysosome (Option A): are involved in intracellular digestion and waste processing but are not primarily involved in intercellular communication.

Peroxisome (Option B): are involved in metabolic processes such as fatty acid oxidation and detoxification, not in intercellular communication.

Genome (Option D): refers to the complete set of genetic material within a cell or organism. While it determines cellular functions, it is not directly involved in intercellular communication.

questions.text: In negative feedback, infinite gain is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Blood volume control by kidney

Explanation:

  • The kidneys play a crucial role in long-term regulation of blood volume and blood pressure through their ability to precisely control the excretion of water and salt.
  • This regulation process involves mechanisms such as the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.
  • When arterial pressure is too high, the kidneys increase the excretion of water and salt, leading to a reduction in blood volume and pressure, returning it to normal.
  • The ability of the kidneys to maintain blood pressure without residual error, over a long period, is what gives rise to the concept of "infinite gain."

Incorrect Options:

Temperature control in the hypothalamus (Option B):

  • The hypothalamus effectively regulates body temperature through various mechanisms (e.g., sweating, shivering), but it does not exhibit infinite gain.
  • It cannot always return temperature deviations to an exact set point without residual error, especially in extreme conditions.

BP control by baroreceptors (Option C):

  • The baroreceptor reflex is crucial for short-term regulation of blood pressure. Baroreceptors respond quickly to changes in blood pressure by adjusting heart rate and vessel diameter.
  • However, this system does not have infinite gain as it cannot completely eliminate deviations and does not sustain long-term pressure regulation.

Infinite gain is not possible (Option D):

  • This option is incorrect because the kidneys' long-term regulation of blood pressure and volume can be described using the infinite gain principle, given their precise and effective feedback mechanism.

questions.text: The least frequency of slow waves is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stomach

Explanation:

  • The Stomach has the least frequency of slow waves
  • The Interstitial Cells of Cajal (ICCs) are the pacemaker cells in the GIT, responsible for generating the slow wave rhythms that control the motility of the digestive tract.
  • These slow waves are not action potentials but can trigger action potentials if their amplitude reaches a threshold.
    • When strong enough, they result in rhythmic contractions of the smooth muscle, contributing to peristalsis and other forms of motility.
  • The frequency of slow waves in different parts of the GIT varies:

GI tract region

Frequency of Slow waves (per minute)

Stomach

3-5

Duodenum

12-20

Jejunum

8-12

Ileum

6-9

Colon

6-10

questions.text: A man in his middle age arrives with a gradual onset of challenges while swallowing both solid and liquid substances over the course of 8 months. The results of a barium swallow test conducted are provided below. What additional examinations should be conducted for this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

Explanation:

  • Given that the barium swallow findings are suggestive of achalasia, the appropriate next steps are to perform an upper GI endoscopy to rule out any other structural causes and oesophagal manometry to confirm the diagnosis.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia such as tumors.

 

Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan (Option B): PET scan is used to detect malignancy or assess metastasis. In the case of achalasia, PET scans are not indicated because this is a benign motility disorder.

Upper GI endoscopy & CECT (Option C): CECT is helpful for evaluating masses, inflammation, or complications (e.g., abscess, perforation), but it would not provide any additional information on oesophagal motility, which is the primary concern in this case.

Upper GI endoscopy & 24-hour pH monitoring (Option D): 24-hour pH monitoring is used primarily for diagnosing GERD, not achalasia.

questions.text: What is the appropriate course of action for managing a 25-year-old male patient who was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident? The patient has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45 mmHg. During examination, hyper-resonance is detected on the right side of the chest. Please refer to the provided chest X-ray for further evaluation.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with a traumatic injury after a road traffic accident. His clinical findings, along with the given chest X-ray, are suggestive of tension pneumothorax.
  • A wide bore needle is inserted into the 5th intercostal space at the mid-axillary line to decompress the pleural space and allow the trapped air to escape, which is the first emergency intervention in suspected tension pneumothorax.
  • After the initial needle decompression, the next step is to insert a chest tube (intercostal drain) in the same location to allow for continuous drainage of air or fluid from the pleural space. (Options A & D ruled out)
  • This will help the lung re-expand and prevent the pneumothorax from recurring.

 

Aspiration of the pleural fluid (Option C) is done for pleural effusion, where fluid accumulates in the pleural space. In this case, the clinical findings suggest pneumothorax, where air is trapped, not fluid. Therefore, aspiration is not the correct approach here.

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Large intracellular proteins

Explanation:

The Gibbs-Donnan effect refers to the impact of non-permeable ions (usually large molecules like intracellular proteins) on the distribution of permeable ions (e.g., sodium, potassium, chloride) across a semipermeable membrane. The presence of these impermeable ions (such as proteins) creates an electrochemical imbalance, leading to the unequal distribution of permeable ions.

  • Non-permeable ions (large proteins) cannot pass through the membrane but affect the distribution of permeable ions by drawing them toward or repelling them from the area to balance the charge and maintain electrical neutrality.
  • This results in an osmotic pressure difference and an electrochemical gradient, where ion concentrations are not equal across the membrane but are still balanced in terms of charge.

Phosphate, Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment, and Calcium in the extracellular compartment (Option A, B, C): Are permeable and do not create the electrochemical gradient central to the Gibbs-Donnan effect.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured, leading to lower lip paralysis in a 30-year-old teacher who underwent parotidectomy?

choices.text: Temporal branch of the facial nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mandibular branch of facial nerve

Explanation:

  • Weakness of the left lower lip after parotid surgery suggests injury to the mandibular branch of the facial nerve.
  • The facial nerve is responsible for motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. It is more commonly at risk during parotid gland surgeries

Complications of Parotidectomy:

Complication

Description

Temporary Facial Palsy
  • Mostly the lower branches of the facial nerve - the marginal mandibular nerve.
  • Most patients recover over time.

Infection

  • Rare, as parotidectomy is a clean procedure.
  • Aseptic precautions and timely drain removal reduce the risk.

Hematoma Formation
  • Uncommon.
  • Careful intraoperative hemostasis can prevent it.
  • Larger hematomas may indicate a bleeding disorder and require management.

Sialocele Formation

  • Occurs if the main ductal system is exposed.
  • Preventable with subcapsular dissection.
  • Treatment: Anticholinergics, aspiration, and pressure dressings.

Retromandibular area hollowing
  • Can occur post-surgery
  • Reduced by placing autologous fat grafts during the surgery.

Frey’s Syndrome
  • Also known as gustatory sweating;
  • Caused by the cross-innervation of sweat glands by regenerating nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve.
  • For mild cases: Give antiperspirants;
  • Severe cases: Botulinum toxin injections or tympanic neurectomy.

Permanent Facial Nerve Weakness
  • D/t transection of the facial nerve during the surgery.

Facial Numbness
  • Permanent numbness of the earlobe,
  • D/t transection of the great auricular nerve during the surgery.

 

Temporal branch of the facial nerve (Option A) controls the upper face (e.g., forehead and eyelid), so injury here would not affect the lower lip.

Cervical branch of the facial nerve (Option B) innervates the platysma muscle, which primarily affects neck and lower face movement but would also cause some degree of neck weakness and not just isolated lower lip weakness.

Parotid duct (Option C) damage can affect the saliva flow but does not result in weakness of the lower lip.

questions.text: All of the following are indications of surgery in a patient of Potts' spine except?

choices.text: Progressive cauda equina syndrome/conus medullaris syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cold abscess without neurological complication

Explanation:

Cold abscess without neurological complication in a patient with Pott's spine can be managed conservatively with anti-tuberculosis medication.

  • Surgery is typically not indicated in such cases, as long as there are no neurological complications.

 

Surgical procedures:

  • Costo-transversectomy
  • Anterolateral decompression
  • HONGKONG procedure: Anterior decompression and spinal fusion
  • Laminectomy

 

Indications for surgery in patients without neurological complications

Indications for surgery in patients with neurological complications
  • Progressive bone destruction despite ATT
  • Failure to respond to conservative therapy
  • Paravertebral abscess when it has increased in size despite medical treatment
  • Spinal instability caused by destruction or collapse, destruction of two or more vertebrae, kyphosis
  • Prevention of severe kyphosis in young children with extensive dorsal lesions
  • Large paraspinal abscess
  • New or worsening neural complications or lack of improvement with conservative treatment
  • Paraplegia of rapid onset or severe paraplegia
  • Late-onset paraplegia
  • Neural arch disease
  • Painful paraplegia in elderly patients
  • Spinal tumor syndrome (epidural spinal tuberculoma without osseous involvement)

 

Middle path regimen in managing Pott’s spine:

Regimen:

  • Medical management in all patients + surgical management in the following situations:
  • Lack of response to chemotherapy
  • Recurrent disease
  • Severe neurological weakness
  • Static or progressive neuro deficit despite a course of ATT
  • Deformity
  • Debilitating pain
  • Instability

questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following can be seen in this child?

A. Bilious vomiting

B. Visible peristalsis from left to right

C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia

D. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B, C and D

Explanation:

  • Visible peristalsis from left to right, hypochloremia and hypokalemia, and Metabolic alkalosis are seen in a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

Definition

It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 - 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age. (Statement A ruled out)
    • Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus.
  • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
    • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
    • Pyloric length > 14 mm
    • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic "string sign" with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

questions.text: Which zone demonstrates the most optimal healing in the repair of a meniscal tear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Red zone

Explanation:

The red zone of the meniscus, which has a good blood supply, also exhibits the best healing potential.

 

Meniscal repair" data-author="" data-hash="12317" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ePN74UlRFNngCnji5Fok1746601931.png" />

 

Meniscal tears are common knee injuries that often require surgical repair.

  • The meniscus is a C-shaped cartilage structure located in the knee joint, providing stability, load distribution, and shock absorption.
  • The meniscus is divided into different zones based on its vascularity and healing potential.
  • The red-white zone, where the vascular and avascular portions of the meniscus meet, has a good healing potential.
  • The red zone is the outermost region of the meniscus and has a good blood supply, allowing for the best healing capacity.
  • The white zone is the innermost region of the meniscus and has a poor blood supply, limiting its healing potential.
  • Repairing a meniscal tear in the red-white zone has the highest likelihood of successful healing due to the presence of a good blood supply.
  • Surgical techniques used for meniscal repair include suturing, meniscal fixation devices, and meniscal transplantation.
  • Postoperative rehabilitation and physical therapy are crucial for optimal recovery and functional outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Tillaux sign?

choices.text: Mass is felt in the periumbilical region
Mass is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line

Explanation:

  • Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery accurately describes the Tillaux sign which is a component of Tillaux’s triad.
  • Tillaux’s triad is associated with mesenteric cysts.

Mesenteric cysts

Definition
  • It presents as a painless abdominal swelling in the umbilical region.
  • Commonly seen in the 2nd decade of life.
  • There is a band of resonance in front of the cyst.

Tillaux's triad for mesenteric cysts
  • A soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region. (Option A ruled out)
  • Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery (Tillaux Sign)
  • A zone of resonance all around.

Complications
  • Torsion of cysts can lead to volvulus of the adjacent bowel.
  • Rupture of the cyst.
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst.
  • Infection

 

Mass is brilliantly transilluminate (Option B): Transillumination refers to shining light through a cyst or mass and observing whether the light passes through, indicating it is filled with fluid or air. However, Tillaux’s sign is about the movement of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery.

Fluctuation is positive (Option D): Fluctuation is a clinical sign used to detect fluid-filled masses noted in cases like hydatid cysts or cystic lesions. However, fluctuation is not specific to the Tillaux sign, which does not focus on detecting fluid content within the mass.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of fall few months back presents with the deformity shown in the image. Probing into history reveals it was managed with traditional treatment. This deformity is likely to be due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Extra-articular fracture of wrist.

Explanation:

  • The image shows a fracture of the wrist that does not involve the joint space, indicating an extra-articular fracture.
  • Extra-articular fractures occur outside the joint, typically involving the distal radius. They are commonly caused by falls or direct trauma to the wrist.
  • Traditional treatment refers to non-surgical methods of managing the fracture, such as casting or splinting.

 

Intra-articular fracture of the wrist (Option A): Intra-articular fractures involve the joint surface. The image does not indicate involvement of the joint.

Boxer's Fracture (Option C): Boxer's fracture typically refers to a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone, often resulting from punching or striking an object with a closed fist.

Barton's Fracture (Option D): Barton's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius, usually involving displacement or subluxation of the radiocarpal joint.

questions.text: Determine the respiratory quotient (RQ) of a patient weighing 50 kg who exhales 200 ml/min of CO2 and consumed 250 ml/min 02.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 0.8

Explanation:

To determine the respiratory quotient (RQ), we use the formula:

  • RQ = VCO2/VO2
  • Given the values:
    • CO2 exhaled (VCO2) = 200 ml/min
    • O2 consumed (VO2) = 250 ml/min
  • Substituting these values into the formula:
    • RQ = 200 ml/min / 250 ml/min RQ = 0.8

questions.text: A bus conductor was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis were noted. According to the CEAP classification system, he would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) C4

Explanation:

  • In this case, the bus conductor has skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis, which are indicative of chronic venous insufficiency, hence classified as C4.
  • The CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification system is used to classify chronic venous disorders

CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification

Clinical classification:

C0

No signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins)

C2

Varicose veins (>3 mm )

C3

Edema

C4
  • C4a - Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b - LDS or atrophic blanche
  • C4c - Corona phlebectatica

C5

C6

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

Etiological classification:

Ec

Anatomical classification:

An

Pathophysiological classification:

Pr

Reflux

Pr,o

Pn

questions.text: Scoliosis screening in school children is done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Forward bending test

Explanation:

Scoliosis screening in school children is typically done using the forward bending test, also known as the Adam's forward bend test.

  • During this test, the child bends forward at the waist with arms extended towards the floor.
  • This allows for the assessment of any asymmetry or abnormal curvature of the spine, which can indicate the presence of scoliosis.
  • Scoliosis is a sideways curvature of the spine.

 

Pathology:

  • Primary Curve: lateral curvature of the spine.
  • Compensatory Curves: curvatures that develop in the opposite direction to maintain balance.
  • Vertebral Rotation: associated with rib prominence (rib hump) on the convex side, particularly in thoracic scoliosis.
  • Affected Areas: any part of the thoracolumbar spine; common patterns include:
    • Dorsal scoliosis
    • Dorso-lumbar scoliosis
    • Lumbar scoliosis

 

Non-structural (transient)

Structural (permanent)

  • Temporary curvature that can be corrected.
     
  • Postural scoliosis:
    • M/c type; Often seen in adolescent girls.
    • Mild leftward convex curve that straightens when bending forward.
       
  • Compensatory scoliosis:
    • Develops to compensate for pelvic tilt (e.g., due to hip disease or a short leg).
    • The curve disappears when the patient sits or when the underlying issue is resolved.
       
  • Sciatic scoliosis:
    • Results from unilateral muscle spasms, often due to a prolapsed intervertebral disc.
  • Involves permanent deformity.
     
  • Idiopathic scoliosis:
    • M/c structural type, can begin in infancy, childhood, or adolescence.
    • M/c in adolescents
    • Infantile scoliosis may resolve or progress, while later-onset scoliosis can lead to significant deformity, especially in the thoracic region.
       
  • Congenital scoliosis:
    • Always associated with vertebral anomalies (e.g., hemivertebrae, block vertebrae, unsegmented bars).
    • These curves can grow rapidly and may lead to neurological deficits.
  • Paralytic scoliosis:
    • Caused by unbalanced paralysis of trunk muscles, commonly due to poliomyelitis, cerebral palsy, or muscular dystrophies.
       
  • Other pathologies: Conditions like neurofibromatosis can cause structural scoliosis with associated kyphosis.

 

 

Radiological Features:

  • X-ray assessment:
    • Full anteroposterior (AP) and lateral X-rays in supine and erect positions are essential for evaluation.
    • Cobb's Angle: Measures curve severity based on the angle formed between the lines passing through the margins of the vertebrae at the curve's ends.
  • Risser's sign:
    It is a classification system that assesses the ossification of the iliac epiphysis, indicating skeletal maturity and growth potential. The ossification begins at ASIS and progresses posteriorly towards the posterior iliac spine. The classification consists of five stages:

 

Risser’s classification

Grade

Ossification of

I

Lateral 25%

II

Lateral 50%

III

Lateral 75%

IV

Lateral 100%

V

Fusion of the ilium
    • Risser stage 4 indicates cessation of spinal growth, while stage 5 correlates with the end of height increase.
    • This classification is crucial for predicting scoliosis progression, as completed growth suggests a reduced risk of curve worsening.

  • Vertebral rotation:
    • Observed through the position of spinous processes and pedicles on AP view.
    • Normally, the spinous process is centered, but rotation causes it to shift to one side, resulting in asymmetry in pedicle positions.
  • Indicators of congenital scoliosis: Possible findings include wedging, hemivertebrae, unsegmented bone bars, and fused ribs.
  • Neurofibromatosis: Due to associated neurofibromas, it may show vertebral body erosion and widened intervertebral foramina.

 

 

Normal curvatures of the spine:

questions.text: Fishtail deformity is seen in fracture of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distal end of humerus

Explanation:

Fishtail deformity is commonly associated with a fracture of distal end of humerus.

  • It is due to separation of articular surface of distal humerus into two fragments resembling the shape of fishtail.

 

Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

Types
  • Type 1: Undisplaced fracture
  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation
  • Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the hand of benediction sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected.
  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

X-ray Findings
  • Three bony parts relationship is maintained.
  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.
  • Disturbed teardrop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 

  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.
  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Management

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)
  • In Late presentation with swelling
    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications
  • Early complications
    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for bone formation in patient with non-union?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) BMP

Explanation:

BMP (Bone Morphogenetic Protein) is a substance that promotes bone formation and is used in the treatment of non-union.

  • BMP is a naturally occurring protein that stimulates the differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells into osteoblasts, the cells responsible for bone formation.
  • It helps in initiating the bone healing process and promoting the growth of new bone tissue.

 

PMMA (Option A): It is a type of bone cement that is used in orthopedic surgeries for fixation, such as in joint replacements or vertebral augmentation procedures.

CaPO4 (Option C): It is not specifically used for bone formation in non-union. Calcium phosphate compounds may be used in bone grafting procedures to provide a scaffold for new bone growth.

CaSO4 (Option D): It is sometimes used as a bone graft substitute or filler in orthopedic procedures, but it is not the primary substance used for bone formation in non-union.

questions.text:
Which of the subsequent factors experiences an elevation in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?

1. FRC

2. TLC

3. VC

4. FEV1/FVC

Explanation:

  • In COPD, FRC and TLC are increased due to air trapping and lung hyperinflation. Vital Capacity (VC) decreases, and the FEV₁/FVC ratio is reduced, typical of obstructive lung diseases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is suffering from increasing difficulty in bending forward with stiffness of the spine and reduced chest movements. A CT was performed and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ankylosing spondylitis

Explanation:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the spine.

 

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

 

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

 

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

 

  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

 

  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

 

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

 

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

 

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

questions.text:
Which of the following tests are not commonly used in osteoporosis:

1. DEXA

2. Bone scan

3. Quantitative CT

4. Chemical analysis

5. X-ray
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 & 3

Explanation:

The tests that are not commonly used in osteoporosis are bone scan (option 2) and quantitative CT (option 3).

  • While DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis, bone scan and quantitative CT are not as commonly employed in routine clinical practice for this purpose.
  • Chemical analysis (option 4) and X-ray (option 5) can provide useful information but may not be as sensitive or specific for assessing bone density and diagnosing osteoporosis as DEXA.

 

Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA):

  • Measures bone mineral density (BMD) at various sites, typically the hip and spine.
  • Findings: T-score and Z-score values are reported, indicating the deviation of the patient's BMD from the average for their age and sex. Lower T-score values indicate lower bone density.

 

Chemical analysis:

  • Involves analysis of bone tissue obtained through biopsy or autopsy.
  • Findings: Provides direct measurement of mineral content and bone quality.

 

X-ray:

  • Commonly used for diagnosing fractures and assessing bone density.
  • Findings: X-rays may show signs of osteoporosis such as vertebral compression fractures or decreased bone density.

 

Blood tests:

  • Measure various markers of bone turnover and metabolism, such as serum calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, and vitamin D levels.
  • Findings: Abnormal levels of these markers may suggest underlying bone disorders.

questions.text: Apart from the abdominal cavity, which body part is included in e-FAST?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thoracic cavity

Explanation:

  • The e-FAST is a rapid, non-invasive ultrasound examination used primarily in trauma settings to detect free fluid (such as blood) in the abdomen or Thorax.
  • If clear lung fields on the chest radiography rule out pneumothorax or hemothorax, eFAST can help detect other sources of bleeding, such as intraperitoneal haemorrhage, to guide further management.
  • It can be used to assess the hepatorenal, splenorenal, and pelvis spaces for fluid that is considered to be blood in a trauma case.

 

Pelvic Cavity (Option A) can be assessed in e-FAST, but the question is about extrabdominal cavities assessed in e-FAST.

Peripheral vessels (Option B) are not normally evaluated with e-FAST.

Dural and subdural spaces (Option D) are assessed by neuroimaging but not by e-FAST.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased urine bilirubin

Explanation:

In Rh incompatibility, maternal antibodies destroy fetal Rh-positive RBCs, leading to hemolysis and excessive unconjugated bilirubin (Option A).

  • Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, preventing urinary excretion. Instead, intestinal bacteria convert it to urobilinogen and stercobilinogen, which are eliminated in stool. (Options B & D)
  • Urine bilirubin consists of conjugated bilirubin, which requires hepatic processing. However, in Rh incompatibility, the liver is overwhelmed, leading to predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and no significant increase in urine bilirubin.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old individual with a history of chronic smoking who is experiencing bluish discoloration of the toes and intermittent claudication, what would be the most suitable investigation to conduct next?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Duplex scan

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the arterial occlusion in the lower limbs is a Duplex scan.
  • The given case with chronic smoking, bluish toes, and intermittent claudication is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), commonly linked to atherosclerosis in smokers.
  • Duplex Doppler ultrasound (DUS) combines B-mode ultrasound for imaging vessels and Doppler ultrasound to assess blood flow, providing an accurate, cost-effective, and non-invasive alternative to angiography for detecting vascular issues.
  • It is useful for initial evaluation but may have limitations in visualising deeper arteries.

 

CT Angiography (Option A) is considered more specific and detailed imaging, and it’s not the first-line investigation for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). It is usually considered when other non-invasive tests (like duplex scans) are inconclusive or when a more detailed assessment is required.

MR Angiography (Option B) is similar to CT angiography, which provides detailed vascular imaging but is not the initial choice. It's generally used when other methods are not feasible or are contraindicated.

Digital subtraction angiography (Option C) is an invasive procedure that involves the injection of contrast dye into the blood vessels followed by X-ray imaging. It is generally reserved for cases where other imaging modalities have not provided sufficient information or when endovascular intervention (such as angioplasty) is planned.

questions.text: What is the significance of a child transferring an object from one hand to the other?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ability to compare objects

Explanation:

  • When a child transfers an object from one hand to another, it signifies their ability to compare objects that appear at 6 months.

 

Visual motor coordination (Option A) refers to using visual input to direct hand movements, such as reaching for objects, which typically develops around 4 months.

For handling small objects (Option C), thumb finger grasp should have been developed, which develops at 8 months of age.

Voluntary release (Option D) typically refers to a disappearance of palmar grasp, which occurs at 4 months of age.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neuropathic ulcer

Explanation:

  • The given image is suggestive of a neurogenic ulcer, which is a common type of ulcer seen in individuals with peripheral neuropathy and is often associated with diabetes or other conditions that cause nerve damage.
  • The loss of sensation in the affected area leads to unawareness of trauma or pressure, making individuals more prone to developing these ulcers over time.
  • Non-healing, painless, shallow, and punched-out appearance is characteristic of these ulcers and they commonly appear on weight-bearing areas like the feet or toes because these areas endure the most pressure.

Clinical features of different ulcers

Features

Venous ulcer

(Option C)

Arterial ulcer

(Option A)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option B)

Pressure ulcer

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the feet, heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful; distal pulses are not palpable, and associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

It is also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

 

Tuberculous ulcer (Option D) occurs when tuberculosis affecting the lungs spreads to the skin. This type of ulcer is relatively uncommon but can develop in individuals with advanced or untreated TB. These ulcers typically have distinct characteristics like an undermined edge and necrotic base and may show signs like scarring or lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following PFT findings in a child do not suggest asthma?

choices.text: Increase in FEV1 > 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Day-night variation of FEV1 >15%

Explanation:

  • In asthma, lung function typically shows significant variability during the day, but the day-night variation of FEV1 is usually <15%. A variation >15% may indicate other conditions such as sleep apnea, or vocal cord dysfunction.

 

Investigations of Asthma:

  • Spirometry: Airflow limitation:
    • Low FEV1 (relative to the percentage of predicted norms)
    • FEV1/FVC ratio <0.80 (Option B)
  • Bronchodilator response (to inhaled ß-agonist) assesses reversibility
    • Reversibility is determined by an increase in either FEV1 >12% or
    • Predicted FEV1 >12% after inhalation of a short-acting ß-agonist (SABA) (Option A)
  • Exercise challenge: Worsening in FEV1 ≥15% (Option D)
  • Daily peak expiratory flow (PEF) or FEV1 monitoring: Day-to-day and/or AM-to-PM variation ≥ 20%
  • Exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO):
    • A value of >20 ppb supports the clinical diagnosis of asthma in children
    • FeNO can be used to predict response to ICS therapy
  • Chest Radiographs:
    • Chest radiographs often appear normal. May show subtle signs such as hyperinflation (flattening of the diaphragms) and peribronchial thickening
  • Allergy Testing: Assesses sensitization to inhalant allergens.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for severe acute malnutrition?

choices.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD
Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Weight for age less than -3 SD

Explanation:

  • Weight for age less than -3 SD is not a criterion for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). Whereas Weight for height < 3 SD is considered as criteria for SAM

 

Severe acute malnutrition:

In a child between 6 months to 5 years of age, the presence of any one or more of the following:

  • Weight for height Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SD in WHO child growth charts (Option A ruled out)
  • Mid arm circumference < 11.5 cm (Option B ruled out)
  • Presence of bipedal edema (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Regarding the initial setting for a patient with blunt chest trauma who has been initiated on mechanical ventilation, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Tidal volume-12ml/kg of actual BW

Explanation:

  • In patients with blunt chest trauma, lung-protective ventilation strategies are crucial to minimize ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI).
  • One of the key components of lung-protective ventilation is limiting tidal volume.
  • The generally recommended tidal volume for patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which includes many cases of severe blunt chest trauma, is 6 ml/kg of predicted body weight (not actual body weight) to reduce the risk of barotrauma.

Lung Protective Ventilation is the current standard in mechanical ventilation which includes the following:

  • Low TV to prevent barotrauma
  • Increase RR-RR can be increased up to 30-35/min to maintain minute ventilation
  • Increase PEEP-Can increase PEEP from 4-12 even up to 16 cm H2O if needed to prevent collapse of alveoli especially in ARDS
  • FiO2 < 0.6 or 60% - If FiO2 > 60%, oxygen radical formation can occur causing worsening of symptoms

Respiratory rate - 12 breaths/min (Option A): It is within the normal range for an adult and can be an appropriate initial setting, although the specific rate may need adjustment based on the patient's condition and blood gas values.

PEEP-5 cm H2O (Option B): Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is used to prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. A setting of 5 cm H2O is a common starting point and can be adjusted based on the patient's oxygenation status.

FiO2-100% (Option C): In the initial stages, a high fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) might be necessary to ensure adequate oxygenation, but it should be titrated down as soon as possible to the lowest level necessary to maintain adequate oxygen saturation, in order to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding adequate thyroid FNAC sampling?

choices.text: 6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells each
10 follicular cell clusters with 6-8 cells each
12 follicular cell clusters with 10-12 cells each

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells each

Explanation:

  • For adequate thyroid FNAC sampling, the recommended guideline is typically 6 follicular clusters, each containing at least 10 cells. This ensures accurate results and reduces the risk of false-negative findings.
  • Thyroid FNAC is a procedure to collect cells for cytology, and adequate sampling is essential for reliable results.
  • The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology (TBSRTC) is a standardised reporting system designed to classify thyroid Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) biopsy results.
  • The system includes six diagnostic categories, ranging from non-diagnostic/unsatisfactory to malignant.

The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology

Diagnostic category

Risk of malignancy (%)

Usual management

Non-diagnostic

5-20

Repeat FNAC with ultrasound guidance

Benign

2-7

Clinical and sonographic follow-up

Atypia of undetermined significance

13-30

Repeat FNAC, molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy, or surveillance

Follicular neoplasm

23-34

Molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy

Suspicious for malignancy

67-83

Molecular testing, lobectomy, or near-total thyroidectomy

Malignant

97-100

Lobectomy or near-total thyroidectomy
  • Other options B, C & D do not meet the recommended criteria for an adequate thyroid FNAC sample.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is not observed following a massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypercalcemia

Explanation:

  • Hypercalcemia is not commonly seen in massive blood transfusions. In fact, the risk is usually the opposite (hypocalcemia) due to citrate-binding calcium.
  • Massive blood transfusion refers to the transfusion of a large volume of blood products over a relatively short period. While blood transfusions can be life-saving, they can also be associated with certain adverse effects.

Complications of massive blood transfusion

Complication

Cause

Effect

Hypothermia

Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C).

Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy) and worsening bleeding.

Coagulopathy

Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage.

Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, increased risk of continued bleeding.

Citrate Toxicity

Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium.

Hypocalcemia leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Hypocalcemia

(Option A ruled out)
  • Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and other blood products are preserved with citrate, an anticoagulant.
  • Citrate binds to ionised calcium (Ca²⁺) in the recipient's blood, reducing the free calcium level - hypocalcemia

Presents as muscle spasms, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased myocardial contractility

Hyperkalemia

(Option D ruled out)

 

 

Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage.

Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest.

Hypokalemia

(Option C ruled out)

 

 

Potassium may shift intracellularly once transfused red blood cells are metabolically revived.

Hypokalemia, causing muscle weakness, paralysis, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Metabolic Alkalosis

Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate.

Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin.

Metabolic Acidosis

Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation.

Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function.

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs.

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion.

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

Volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload.

Pulmonary edema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure.

Iron Overload

Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron.

Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time.

Hemolytic Reactions

ABO or Rh incompatibility.

Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causing fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock.

Allergic Reactions

Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products.

Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock).

Bacterial Contamination

Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage.

Sepsis is characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.

questions.text: What risks are associated with the initiation of tamoxifen in a patient diagnosed with unilateral breast cancer?

choices.text: Breast cancer, on the other side

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endometrial cancer

Explanation:

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used in the treatment of breast cancer, which has a potential risk for endometrial cancer.
  • While it is effective at preventing estrogen from binding to receptors in breast tissue, it can act as an estrogen agonist in the endometrium.
  • Prolonged use of Tamoxifen leads to endometrial hyperplasia, which is a significant risk factor for developing endometrial cancer.

 

Ovarian cancer (Option A): Tamoxifen does not significantly increase the risk of ovarian cancer.

Breast cancer on the other side (Option C): Tamoxifen reduces the risk of contralateral breast cancer by blocking estrogen receptors in the breast tissue, hence lowering the risk.

Cervical cancer (Option D): There is no direct association between tamoxifen use and an increased risk of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following methods cannot be used to determine cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Capnography

Explanation:

  • Capnography is a monitoring technique that measures the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO₂) in exhaled breath.
  • It is commonly used to assess ventilation and end-tidal CO, levels but does not provide direct information about cardiac output.

Cardiac output is volume of blood ejected by the heart into the aorta per minute and it is measured by:

Method

Principle

Measurement Basis

Key Considerations

Fick Principle

Oxygen uptake and arteriovenous difference

Oxygen content in blood

Accurate in steady states

Indicator/Thermal Dilution Method (Option A ruled out)

Indicator concentration dilution

Injected dye or tracer

Requires precise indicator handling

Echocardiography (Transthoracic/transesophageal) (Options C & D ruled out)

Ultrasound visualization and flow velocity

Stroke volume estimation

Non-invasive, real-time data

Thoracic Electrical Bioimpedance

Electrical impedance changes

Impedance fluctuations

Sensitive to external factors

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency can result in seizures in newborns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pyridoxine

Explanation:

  • Deficiency of pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) can lead to refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system, and its deficiency can disrupt normal brain development and function, leading to seizures in newborns.

 

Deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1) (Option B) can result in a condition called beriberi, which primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems but does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) (Option C) is necessary for energy production and the metabolism of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. While riboflavin deficiency can lead to various symptoms, including skin and eye abnormalities, it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) (Option D) is involved in the synthesis of coenzyme A, which is essential for energy metabolism. Deficiency of pantothenic acid is not associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6):

  • RDA: 0.1-0.3 mg/day
  • Dietary Sources: Banana, wheat germ, rice, sunflower seeds, fish, poultry.

 

Pyridoxine (B6) deficiency

Cause

High protein intake.

Certain medications (eg. Isoniazid)

Oral contraceptives.

Dialysis.

Clinical features:

Infants: Irritability, seizures, vomiting, failure to thrive.

Adults: Peripheral neuritis, cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

Dependency Syndromes: Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy, Vitamin B6-responsive anemia.

Diagnosis:

Low AST/ALT, high urinary xanthurenic acid, EEG response to pyridoxine.

Treatment:

Convulsions: 100 mg pyridoxine IM/IV, then oral intake.

Dependency: 2-10 mg IM or 10-100 mg orally daily.

questions.text: While taking your morning stroll in the park, you come across an individual who is unconscious and lying on the ground. What would be the most appropriate course of action to take next from the given choices?

choices.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help; Defibrillate if no pulse
Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

Explanation:

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities and irregular respiration. The heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is a grimace and some flexion. What is the APGAR score for this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 5

Explanation:

In the given case:

  • Appearance: Pink body with blue extremities (score = 1)
  • Pulse rate: 80 beats/min (score = 1)
  • Grimace: Shows grimace (score = 1)
  • Activity: Some flexion (score = 1)
  • Respiratory effort: Irregular breathing (score = 1)

Therefore, the total score is 5.

 

APGAR score:

  • The APGAR score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn’s condition.
  • It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.
  • Resuscitation must be initiated before the 1 minute score is assigned. Therefore, it is not used to guide the resuscitation.

 

 

0

1

2

Appearance

Completely blue or pale

The body is pink, and the extremities are blue

Completely pink

Pulse rate

Absent

<100/min

>100/min

Grimace

No response

Grimaces only

Coughs/sneezes

Activity

Limp and flaccid

Some flexion present

Flexed posture and actively moving limbs

Respiratory effort

None

Slow and irregular

Normal/strong

 

Interpretation:

  • Normal APGAR score is ≥7
  • Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0
  • Score for severe birth asphyxia = 0 - 3

questions.text: In a patient with laryngeal cancer who has undergone a total laryngectomy, determine the mode of voice production depicted in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Electro larynx

Explanation:

  • Electro larynx: After a total laryngectomy, patients can use an electro larynx for voice production.
  • It is a handheld device that vibrates to generate sound, which the patient then shapes into speech by moving their mouth.
  • The electro larynx is an effective alternative for patients who cannot use a tracheoesophageal prosthesis and provides a mechanical, yet functional, voice.

Electro Larynx:

  • The electro larynx is commonly used in patients who have undergone a total laryngectomy, a procedure that removes the larynx and disrupts normal voice production.
  • The device works by emitting vibrations, which the patient can articulate to form words. Although it can be mechanical-sounding, it remains a popular and accessible method for speech restoration.

Incorrect Options:

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis (Option A): is incorrect because it involves the use of a small valve between the trachea and esophagus to produce speech, not a mechanical device.

Chicago implant (Option B): is incorrect because the Chicago implant is a type of prosthesis used for tracheoesophageal speech but does not directly generate sound like the electro larynx.

Esophageal speech (Option D): is incorrect because this method involves swallowing air and releasing it from the esophagus to produce speech, which is different from using a mechanical device like the electro larynx.

questions.text: A senior resident in the hospital is performing the following clinical examination, as shown in the image below. Which of the following structures will not be visible to him?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Arytenoids

Explanation:

  • Arytenoids: The arytenoid cartilage is located in the larynx and is not visible during a posterior rhinoscopy, which examines the nasal cavity and nasopharynx using a mirror or endoscope.
  • The arytenoids are situated lower down in the larynx and are not accessible through the posterior nasal passage.

Posterior Rhinoscopy:

  • Posterior rhinoscopy is a clinical examination technique used to visualize the posterior part of the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, and adjacent structures like the adenoids, torus tubarius, and the upper surface of the soft palate.
  • This procedure is typically performed with a mirror or flexible endoscope, allowing the examiner to assess the nasopharyngeal area for any abnormalities.
  • Structures located in the nasopharynx and upper airway, but not the larynx, will be visible.

Incorrect Options:

Adenoids (Option A): are visible during posterior rhinoscopy, as they are located in the nasopharynx, which is the area examined in this procedure.

Torus tubarius (Option C): is the elevation of the mucosa over the eustachian tube orifice and is also visible during posterior rhinoscopy, being located in the nasopharynx.

Upper surface of soft palate (Option D): is visible during posterior rhinoscopy as it is part of the posterior oropharyngeal area and can be observed during the examination.

questions.text: Which of the options accurately represents a valid statement concerning retroperitoneal trauma?

choices.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury, whether blunt or penetrative, should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

Explanation:

  • Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically, is the correct statement.
  • In Zone 2, expanding hematoma confined to the lateral retroperitoneum without active bleeding and hemodynamically stable patient angioembolisation is a suitable option to prevent or control bleeding while avoiding the risks associated with open surgery.
  • Angioembolization is a minimally invasive procedure that involves the selective occlusion of bleeding vessels.
  • The retroperitoneum is divided into three zones for intraoperative management in blunt trauma:

 

Zone I – Central

  • Associated with injuries of
