    • The aorta & its proximal branches
    • Inferior vena cava & its proximal tributaries
  • Management: Central hematoma - exploration with proximal & distal vascular control (Option A ruled out).

 

Zone 2 - Lateral

  • Structures located - Distal renal vessels
  • Management:
    • Lateral hematoma (renal in origin) - managed nonoperatively (angioembolisation) (Option C)
    • Pulsatile hematoma or penetrating injury present - exploration.

Zone 3 - Pelvic

  • Confined to the retroperitoneal zone of the pelvis
  • Structures located - Iliac vessels
  • Management: Pelvic hematoma is exceptionally difficult to control. Usually, it should not be opened. It is managed by packing/angioembolisation. Explored only if there is expanding or pulsatile, or penetrating injury present. (Option B ruled out)

Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilised to the right to visualise the Aorta (Option D). This is incorrect because the Mattox maneuver, also known as a left medial visceral rotation, is a surgical step to explore and handle Zone 1 and 2 retroperitoneal injuries, it involves mobilising the left colon (not the ascending colon) to gain better access to the aorta and other retroperitoneal structures for surgery.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic maneuver performed by an ENT surgeon when a patient presents with vertigo but no hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

Explanation:

  • Dix-Hallpike maneuver: The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), a common cause of vertigo.
  • It involves rapidly moving the patient from a sitting position to a supine position with their head turned to one side, and then observing for signs of nystagmus (involuntary eye movement).
  • BPPV typically presents with vertigo triggered by head movement but no hearing loss, making this maneuver the correct diagnostic tool for such cases.

Dix-Hallpike Maneuver:

  • The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used to diagnose BPPV, where tiny calcium crystals (canaliths) become dislodged and move into the semicircular canals of the inner ear. This leads to episodes of vertigo.
  • The maneuver helps to provoke the vertigo and nystagmus by positioning the patient's head in a way that stimulates the affected semicircular canal, aiding in diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Yacovino maneuver (Option A): is incorrect because it is not a standard diagnostic maneuver for vertigo. The Yacovino maneuver is typically used to test for peripheral vestibular dysfunction.

Epley’s maneuver (Option C): is incorrect because while Epley’s maneuver is used for treating BPPV, it is not used for diagnosis. It helps reposition the canaliths to alleviate the vertigo.

Simon's maneuver (Option D): is incorrect as it is not commonly used for vertigo diagnosis. It is a historical maneuver that was more relevant in older diagnostic practices.

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis

Explanation:

  • Acute pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas, often linked to biliary causes like gallstones or choledocholithiasis; however, when choledocholithiasis is absent, and no bile duct obstruction is present, ERCP is not typically recommended.
  • ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is an invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to examine and treat disorders of the bile ducts, pancreatic ducts, and gallbladder.
  • In the given case, non-invasive imaging like abdominal ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI is sufficient to assess the pancreas and biliary tree, and ERCP is reserved for patients with evidence of bile duct obstruction.

 

Recurrent pancreatitis (Option A) can be caused by bile duct stones, pancreatic duct abnormalities, or strictures. ERCP helps by identifying obstructions, structural changes, and stones in the bile duct or pancreatic duct. It also allows therapeutic interventions such as stone removal or stenting of the bile duct. Therefore, ERCP is often used in recurrent pancreatitis if there is suspicion of biliary causes.

Unexplained jaundice (Option B) can arise from a variety of causes, but one of the most common is obstruction of the bile duct, often by stones, tumours, or strictures. ERCP is an excellent diagnostic tool for identifying the cause of jaundice.

Periampullary mass (Option C) is a growth near the Ampulla of Vater, and ERCP is particularly useful in the diagnosis of these as it provides detailed imaging of the ampulla of Vater and helps identify the location, extent, and nature of the mass, aiding in further management decisions.

questions.text: What is the commonly used name for the view shown in the radiograph below, which is used to assess the frontal sinus more effectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Caldwell view

Explanation:

  • Caldwell view: The Caldwell view is a type of X-ray used to assess the frontal sinuses and is especially useful for evaluating the anterior and posterior ethmoidal sinuses.
  • In this view, the patient’s head is tilted back with the X-ray beam directed at the forehead at a 15° angle.
  • This positioning helps provide a clear view of the frontal sinuses.

Caldwell View:

  • The Caldwell view is commonly used in radiology to evaluate the sinuses, especially the frontal sinuses.
  • This projection is typically used for sinus X-rays to assess conditions like sinusitis, fractures, or other abnormalities of the frontal and ethmoid sinuses.

Incorrect Options:

Water’s view (Option A): is incorrect because the Water’s view is typically used to visualize the maxillary sinuses and is not particularly aimed at frontal sinus evaluation.

Pierre’s view (Option C) is incorrect because Pierre’s view is not a standard or widely used radiological term.

Towne’s view (Option D): is incorrect because the Towne’s view is used for imaging the skull, particularly for assessing the occipital region and is not focused on the frontal sinuses.

questions.text: Please identify the structure indicated in the endoscopic image of the right nasal cavity.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inferior turbinate

Explanation:

  • The inferior turbinate is the largest of the three turbinates in the nasal cavity, located along the bottom part of the nasal passages.
  • During endoscopic examination of the right nasal cavity, the inferior turbinate is typically the most prominent structure visible.
  • It plays an important role in conditioning the air we breathe by warming, moistening, and filtering it before it enters the respiratory tract.

Inferior Turbinate:

  • The inferior turbinate is composed of bone and covered with mucosa.
  • Its main function is to regulate airflow and humidify the air that enters the nasal passages.
  • It is most commonly involved in conditions like nasal obstruction or rhinitis and may become enlarged due to various inflammatory conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Middle turbinate (Option B): is incorrect because the middle turbinate is positioned above the inferior turbinate and is typically smaller in size. It is located in the middle meatus and can be visible in endoscopic examinations, but it's not the structure being referred to here.

Superior turbinate (Option C): is incorrect because the superior turbinate is the smallest and located towards the top of the nasal cavity. It is not typically the most prominent structure in routine endoscopic views.

Uncinate process (Option D): is incorrect because the uncinate process is part of the ethmoid bone and located near the middle meatus. It is often visible in nasal endoscopy but is not as prominent as the inferior turbinate.

questions.text:
Determine the accurate order of the pathways involved in the auditory system.

A. Superior Olivary nucleus
B. Cochlear Nucleus
C. Inferior Colliculi
D. Lateral lemniscus
E. Medial geniculate ganglion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) BADCE

Explanation:

The accurate order for the auditory pathway is as follows:

  1. Cochlear Nucleus (B): The first structure where auditory information from the cochlea synapses. It is located in the brainstem.
  2. Superior Olivary Nucleus (A): After the cochlear nucleus, the auditory information is relayed to the superior olivary nucleus, which is involved in sound localization and the processing of binaural auditory signals.
  3. Lateral Lemniscus (D): The lateral lemniscus transmits auditory signals from both the superior olivary nucleus and the cochlear nucleus to higher brainstem centers.
  4. Inferior Colliculi (C): Located in the midbrain, the inferior colliculi are involved in auditory processing and reflexes.
  5. Medial Geniculate Ganglion (E): The final relay station in the thalamus before auditory signals reach the auditory cortex for perception.

Auditory Pathway:

  • The auditory system processes sound information starting from the cochlea.
  • The cochlear nucleus receives the initial signal, which is then sent to the superior olivary nucleus for sound localization.
  • The signal then travels via the lateral lemniscus to the inferior colliculi for further processing, followed by the medial geniculate ganglion in the thalamus before reaching the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe.

ABCDE (Option A): This order is incorrect because lateral lemniscus comes after the superior olivary nucleus and should not be placed before it.

BACDE (Option C): Incorrect because the inferior colliculi should come before the medial geniculate ganglion, not after it.

BAEDC (Option D): Incorrect as the medial geniculate ganglion should not come before the inferior colliculi.

questions.text: Which drug is most likely responsible for visual disturbances and contraction of the visual field in a patient who was taking antiepileptics for seizure management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vigabatrin

  • Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic medication commonly associated with visual disturbances, particularly visual field defects, such as concentric visual field constriction or "tunnel vision."
  • It is primarily used to treat refractory seizures and infantile spasms in patients with epilepsy.
  • However, a significant side effect of vigabatrin is the risk of visual field defects, which can vary in severity, ranging from mild to severe. The mechanism behind this adverse effect involves the drug's irreversible inhibition of the enzyme GABA transaminase, leading to elevated levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the central nervous system.
  • Visual field defects caused by vigabatrin are usually bilateral and symmetrical, and they may worsen with prolonged use.
  • Regular monitoring of visual fields is essential for patients on vigabatrin to detect any changes early and manage the side effects appropriately.

Anti-epileptic drugs that require ophthalmic monitoring:

Drug

Ophthalmic side effects

Vigabatrin

Significant risk of permanent peripheral visual field defects (visual field constriction) and retinal toxicity.

Topiramate

Potential for acute myopia, secondary angle-closure glaucoma, and visual disturbances such as blurred vision and diplopia.

Phenobarbitone (Option A) is an antiepileptic drug that is not typically associated with visual disturbances or visual field defects. It works through a different mechanism and does not commonly cause visual issues as a side effect.

Ethosuximide (Option C) is mainly used for treating absence seizures. It is not associated with visual disturbances or visual field defects and is not known to cause such side effects.

Levetiracetam (Option D) is an antiepileptic drug generally well-tolerated by patients. While it can cause other side effects like drowsiness, headache, or mood changes, it is not linked to visual disturbances or visual field constriction.

questions.text: The response on stimulation of the muscarinic receptor is _
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Erection:

Erection is mediated by muscarinic receptors of parasympathetic system.

  • Muscarinic receptors are involved in the parasympathetic control of penile erection (M3 receptor).
  • Stimulation of these receptors leads to the release of nitric oxide (NO) in the penile arteries and smooth muscle relaxation, resulting in increased blood flow to the erectile tissue and the subsequent achievement and maintenance of an erection.
  • Ejaculation (Option B) is mediated by the adrenergic system (ɑ1 receptor)

Bronchodilation (Option C): Stimulation of muscarinic receptors primarily leads to bronchoconstriction, not bronchodilation. When muscarinic receptors are activated in the airways, smooth muscle contraction occurs, which narrows the airways and causes bronchoconstriction.

Increased myocardial contractility (Option D): Muscarinic receptor stimulation has a negative chronotropic and inotropic effect on the heart. Activation of these receptors in the heart results in a decrease in heart rate (chronotropic effect) and a reduction in myocardial contractility (inotropic effect), thereby lowering the force of cardiac contraction.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, and CT head reveals multiple calcified parenchymal cysts. What is the correct management approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Continue antiepileptics

Explanation:

  • Multiple calcified parenchymal cysts on CT head are characteristic of Neurocysticercosis (NCC) in the inactive (calcified) stage.
  • Seizures in calcified NCC are caused by gliotic scarring rather than active infection, so the primary treatment is antiepileptic therapy.
  • Antiparasitic drugs (Albendazole, Praziquantel) are ineffective in the calcified stage and can worsen inflammation.
  • Steroids are used only if perilesional edema is present, but they do not alter the course of calcified cysts.
  • The combination of albendazole and praziquantel is recommended for effective treatment of multiple viable cysts (>2 cysts).

Treatment of Neurocysticercosis

  1. Seizure Management: Anticonvulsant therapy is initiated upon seizure presentation. Stop if follow-up imaging shows resolution and no seizures for 24 months.
  2. Anthelmintic Therapy: Depends on the lesion stage.
  3. Cystic Lesions Treatment:
    • Albendazole: Drug of choice for parenchymal Neurocysticercosis (15 mg/kg daily for 10-14 days). Recommended for 1-2 parenchymal cysts.
    • Praziquantel: Alternative option (50 mg/kg in 3 divided doses daily for 10 days).
    • Albendazole + Praziquantel: For >2 viable cysts (Praziquantel: 50 mg/kg/day for 10-14 days).
    • Prednisolone: 10 mg three times daily for 14 days, starting 1 day before Albendazole or Praziquantel. Given to suppress the inflammation during the natural course of the disease.
  4. Stages of Cysts:
    • Viable Cysts: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Vesicular & Colloidal Stages: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Granulonodular Stage: Some experts recommend treatment.
    • Calcified Lesions: Do not require treatment with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Small, Solitary Cerebral Cysts: Often resolve without treatment.
  5. Operative Intervention: Indicated for hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A psychiatric patient was started on lithium for the management of bipolar disorder. To monitor the blood lithium levels, at what time interval should the blood sample be collected after the administration of lithium tablets?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - After 12 hours

  • Monitoring blood lithium levels is crucial to ensure the therapeutic effectiveness and safety of lithium treatment in patients with bipolar disorder.
  • After taking lithium tablets orally, the drug requires time to be absorbed, distributed, and reach a steady-state concentration in the blood. Consequently, blood samples for monitoring lithium levels are generally taken approximately 12 hours after the last dose.
  • Measuring lithium levels 12 hours after administration provides an accurate assessment of the drug's concentration, enabling healthcare providers to adjust the dosage if necessary.

After 24 hours (Option A): Collecting a blood sample 24 hours after administering lithium may lead to inaccurate lithium level readings. By this time, the drug could have been metabolized and eliminated to a considerable degree, resulting in a sample that no longer reflects the therapeutic concentration.

After 6 hours (Option C): Drawing a blood sample just 6 hours after lithium administration may not provide an accurate measurement of its levels. At this point, the drug may not have reached its peak concentration, and the sample may not accurately reflect the steady-state levels needed for proper monitoring.

Immediately after taking tablets (Option D): Taking a blood sample immediately after administering lithium would not provide an accurate representation of the drug's concentration in the bloodstream. The drug requires time to be absorbed and distributed before it reaches its peak concentration.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about chancroid?

A. School of fish appearance

B. Bleeds on touch

C. Painless

D. Cullen sign
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A & B only

Explanation:

Chancroid (Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi)

  • Highly contagious bacterial STD.
  • Painful genital ulcer with ragged edges and a soft base.
  • Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo formation).
  • H. ducreyi culture is gold standard but has low sensitivity
  • School of Fish Appearance: Haemophilus ducreyi appears in parallel chains resembling a "school of fish" on Gram stain.
  • Bleeds on Touch: Chancroid ulcers are friable and tend to bleed on touch.
  • Common in tropical regions and associated with sex workers.

Features of H. ducreyi:

  • Gram-negative coccobacillus
  • Fastidious, requiring X factor but not V factor
  • Forms characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" arrangements in Gram stains
  • Safety pin appearance of bipolar staining.

Clinical features of chancroid:

  • Painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and a purulent base
  • Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes)
  • Incubation period of 3-10 days

Diagnosis:

  1. Clinical presentation
  2. Gram stain of ulcer exudate
  3. Culture on selective media (challenging and low sensitivity)
  4. PCR (most sensitive method)
  5. Differential diagnosis includes syphilis, herpes simplex, and lymphogranuloma venereum

Treatment:

  • Azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR
  • Ceftriaxone 250mg IM single dose, OR
  • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally twice daily for 3 days, OR
  • Erythromycin 500mg orally three times daily for 7 days
  • Treatment of sexual partners is crucial

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is NOT bactericidal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Thioacetazone

  • Thioacetazone is not bactericidal drug, it is a bacteriostatic drug & is never used alone & only used as combination with first-line TB drugs.

General properties of first-line drugs in TB:

Name of drug

Isoniazid

Rifampin

Pyrazinamide

Ethambutol

Streptomycin

MOA

Inhibition of synthesis of mycolic acids (cell wall).

It also inhibits mycobacterium DHFR, thereby interfering with nucleic acid synthesis.

Interrupts RNA synthesis by binding to mycobacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis by getting converted into pyrazinoic acid

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in mycolic acid incorporation in the cell wall

Inhibits 30S ribosomal protein synthesis

ROA

Oral

Oral

Oral

Oral

Intramuscular

Cellularity

Intracellular and extracellular

Intracellular and extracellular

Intracellular

Extracellular

Extracellular

Mechanism

Bactericidal

Bactericidal

Bactericidal

Bacteriostatic

 

Bactericidal

Bacteria inhibited

Rapidly dividing M.TB

Slow growers

Slow growers

Rapidly dividing M.TB

Rapidly dividing M.TB

questions.text: In renal failure, which of the listed medications does not require dosage adjustment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Linagliptin

  • Linagliptin is the only DPP-4 inhibitor among the options that does not require dosage adjustment in patients with renal impairment.
  • In contrast, drugs like Sitagliptin, Saxagliptin, and Vildagliptin are contraindicated in patients with severe renal failure due to their renal excretion.
  • Linagliptin is primarily metabolized by the liver, which is why it is safe to use without dose adjustments in renal impairment.

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors

MOA
  • Increase Incretin Levels: Prevents degradation of incretin hormones (GLP-1 and GIP)
  • Enhance Insulin Secretion from the pancreas in response to meals. (no risk of hypoglycemia)
  • Reduce Glucagon Secretion
  • Maintain neutral weight

Uses
  • Oral hypoglycemic drug (type-2 diabetes)

Drugs
  1. Linagliptin: Safe in renal failure
  2. Vildagliptin: Hepatotoxic
  3. Alogliptin
  4. Sitagliptin
  5. Saxagliptin (Option B):
    1. Metabolised by CYP3A4, it has more drug interactions.
    2. Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.
    3. Risk of congestive heart failure.

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
    • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm-to-touch nodule in the neck. Anaerobic culture of the biopsy material reveals colonies resembling a molar tooth appearance, and Gram staining shows gram-positive branching rods. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Penicillin

Explanation:

  • Penicillin is the drug of choice for actinomycosis, a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Actinomyces species. High-dose intravenous penicillin, followed by oral therapy for an extended duration, is required to eradicate the infection.

Features

Actinomycetes

Acid-fastness

Nonacid-fast

O2 Requirement

Anaerobe

Habitat
  • Found as oral flora
  • Infections occur endogenously

Risk factors

Immunocompetent also

Clinical forms

Cervicofascial, abdominal, and others.

Granules

Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli, and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance)

Culture
  • Spidery molar teeth colony in solid media
  • Fluffy ball at the bottom of the liquid medium

Treatment

Penicillin

Incorrect Options:

Doxycycline (Option A): Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic effective against various bacterial infections, including atypical organisms and some anaerobes. However, it is not the first-line treatment for Actinomyces infections, which require prolonged therapy with beta-lactam antibiotics.

Cotrimoxazole (Option B): Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) has good coverage against certain gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria but is not the preferred treatment for Actinomyces infections. The organism is best treated with prolonged penicillin therapy.

Surgical drainage (Option D): Although surgical drainage may be necessary in cases with extensive abscess formation or sinus tracts, antibiotic therapy remains the mainstay of treatment. Penicillin is the first-line agent for Actinomyces infections.

questions.text: If codeine is coming to the market in combination with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive, this combination ____________.

choices.text: Should not be used due to risk of addiction
Can be used as both have different mechanisms of action
Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Should not be used as it is irrational

  • Codeine and dextromethorphan are both antitussives that act on the central nervous system to suppress cough.
  • Additionally, codeine is an opioid with risks of addiction and respiratory depression, while dextromethorphan is non-addictive.
  • Combining them is irrational as they have similar mechanisms of action, offering no added benefit.

Should not be used due to risk of addiction (Option A) : Codeine, being an opioid, carries addiction potential, dextromethorphan is not addictive. Combining these drugs does not increase the risk of addiction.

Can be used as both have different mechanisms of action (Option B): This option suggests the combination is beneficial because codeine and dextromethorphan have different mechanisms of action. However, both drugs act on the brain to suppress the cough reflex in a similar way, so combining them does not offer any additional therapeutic benefit.

Can be used to treat cough effectively (Option D) : This option implies the combination is effective for treating cough. However, combining codeine with dextromethorphan provides no extra benefit over using dextromethorphan alone. The combination is considered irrational, and safer alternatives are available for cough treatment.

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanisms of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 5-HT agonist

  • 5-HT agonists, such as triptans, are commonly prescribed for migraine treatment. These drugs stimulate 5-HT receptors, leading to vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels. However, in patients with a history of angina/MI, they may also cause vasoconstriction in coronary arteries, potentially triggering chest pain or even a myocardial infarction due to reduced blood flow to the heart.

Migraine

Pathophysiology

  • Migraine is characterized by a pulsating unilateral headache that comes in bouts lasting 4-48 hours and is associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, flashes of light, and vertigo.
  • 5th cranial nerve stimulation (5-HT1F receptor) → Release of neurotransmitters like CGRP, neurokinin, Nitrous Oxide, 5-HT → Dilation of meningeal vessels causing headache

Drugs used in acute migraine

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

5-HT antagonists (Option A) block serotonin’s effects and are generally not linked to chest pain in patients with angina/MI. While they may have other side effects, they are not typically associated with chest pain in this context.

Calcium Channel Blocker action (Option C) are used to treat angina and hypertension by causing vasodilation. They are not typically associated with chest pain in patients with angina/MI.

Nitric oxide-mediated vasodilation (Option D) promotes blood vessel relaxation and is used in conditions like angina. It is not commonly linked to causing chest pain in patients with a history of angina/MI.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants causes the least sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Mirtazapine:

Mirtazapine, an atypical antidepressant, is generally associated with a lower incidence of sexual dysfunction compared to other antidepressants. It works by enhancing the release of norepinephrine and serotonin.

  • Unlike selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like fluoxetine (Option A) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) like venlafaxine (Option B), mirtazapine (Option C) has a different mechanism of action.
  • It is generally linked to a lower risk of sexual dysfunction compared to SSRIs and SNRIs.
  • This is because it does not directly inhibit serotonin reuptake, which is believed to contribute to sexual side effects.
  • Instead, mirtazapine primarily works by antagonizing certain serotonin and alpha-2 receptors, which increases the release of norepinephrine and serotonin.

questions.text: Which of the listed medications aids in the stimulation of bone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Teriparatide

  • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that stimulates bone formation by promoting osteoblast activity.
  • Unlike calcitonin, raloxifene, and bisphosphonates, which primarily aim to inhibit bone resorption, teriparatide actively stimulates bone growth and is used to treat osteoporosis.

 

 

Drugs used in Osteoporosis:

Pharmacological Agent

Mechanism of Action

Bisphosphonates (Option C)

Interfere with osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone resorption.

Calcitonin (Option A)

Inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption.

Denosumab

 

It inhibits the RANK ligand, which is essential for osteoclast formation and function.

Estrogen/Raloxifene (Option B)

Inhibit osteoclast activity and slow bone loss.

Cinacalcet

Indirectly reduces bone resorption by lowering PTH levels. (by stimulating CaSR receptors)

Teriparatide

A recombinant form of PTH stimulates osteoblast activity.

Strontium Ranelate

Dual action: It promotes bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts and decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity.

questions.text: Which groups of individuals should be screened for cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 21 to 65 year old females

Explanation:

  • Screening for cervical cancer is recommended for females between the ages of 21 and 65 years. This is the age group at higher risk for developing cervical cancer due to the prevalence of human papillomavirus (HPV) infections. Regular screening with Pap smear or HPV testing can help detect cervical abnormalities and prevent the development of cervical cancer.
  • For women aged 21-65 years, the recommended cervical cancer screening guideline is co-testing with a Pap smear and HPV testing every 5 years if negative.

Pap smear

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear: Cells are collected with a spatula or brush, smeared onto a slide, and immediately fixed with a spray fixative or by immersing in 95% ethanol with/without ether
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Considerations
  • Sensitivity: A single Pap test has a sensitivity of 47-62% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions.
  • HPV co-testing: Combining the Pap smear with HPV DNA testing significantly improves screening accuracy.
  • Colposcopy: Colposcopy, with biopsy if indicated, is the gold standard for evaluating abnormal Pap results.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years (OptionA), with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

Contraindications

Avoided during menstruation. (Relative C/I)


While older women may still be at risk for cervical cancer, routine screening is not recommended after the age of 65 (Option A) if previous screenings have been negative.

Cervical cancer is rare in women younger than 21 years (Option B), and routine screening is not recommended in this age group.

Routine screening for cervical cancer is not recommended for teenagers (Option D) unless there are specific risk factors or symptoms present.

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Drug deposition in the oropharynx

  • Metered dose inhalers (MDIs) are commonly used to deliver medication directly into the respiratory system to treat conditions such as asthma and COPD.
  • However, one of the drawbacks of MDIs is that a significant portion of the medication can deposit in the oropharynx (back of the throat) instead of reaching the intended target in the lungs. This can reduce the effectiveness of the medication and may lead to inadequate symptom relief.
  • Using a large-volume spacer will reduce the amount of drug deposited in the oropharynx, reducing the amount reaching GIT and reducing systemic side effects.
  • A spacer reduces the velocity & size of particles entering the upper airways.

Bacterial contamination (Option A) can be a concern with medical devices, but it is not the most common issue associated with metered-dose inhalers. Proper cleaning and maintenance can reduce the risk of contamination.

Does not provide multiple doses (Option B): Metered-dose inhalers are designed to provide multiple doses. They contain a canister that delivers a specific number of doses, with each actuation releasing a measured amount of medication. It is important to track the number of remaining doses to ensure the inhaler isn't empty when needed.

Not portable (Option D): Metered-dose inhalers are compact and portable, making them easy to carry and use in different settings. Therefore, "not portable" is not a valid drawback of metered-dose inhalers.

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy, and an X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drugs is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Vincristine

  • Based on the presentation of pallor, lymphadenopathy, and the X-ray showing punched-out and beveled lesions, LCH (Langerhans cell histiocytosis) is the possible diagnosis.
  • While vincristine is used in the treatment of certain cancers, it is not typically used as a primary treatment for Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Skeletal and Radiological findings of LCH:

  • Beveled-edge skull lesions (classic sign)
  • Lytic bone lesions (especially in the skull, spine, and long bones)
  • Button sequestra representing residual bone
  • Geographic skull
  • Mandible: Floating tooth (loss of lamina dura)
  • Spine: Vertebra plana (M/c cause of vertebra plana in children)

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs exacerbates myasthenia and is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis? 


	Lidocaine
	Digene
	Meropenem
	Phenytoin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 1 & 2

  • Lidocaine is a local anesthetic that may worsen myasthenia gravis by affecting neuromuscular function, potentially increasing weakness and fatigue due to its interference with acetylcholine receptors.
    Digene (antacid) contains magnesium or aluminum salts, which can reduce the absorption of medications like pyridostigmine, commonly used in myasthenia gravis, to enhance muscle strength.

Drugs aggravating myasthenia gravis:

  • Local Anaesthetics
  • Magnesium
  • Antibiotics: Aminoglycosides, Quinolones, Macrolides
  • Beta-blockers
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Penicillamine
  • Quinine derivatives
  • NDMR

questions.text:
What is the drug that decreases mortality in patients with COVID-19 among the options provided?

A. Dexamethasone
B. Remdesivir
C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Only A

Explanation:

  • Dexamethasone (A) is a corticosteroid that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe cases of COVID-19 by reducing inflammation and preventing excessive immune responses.
  • In severe cases, Dexamethasone is administered at 6mg IV/PO once for 10 days/until discharge.

Other Options:

  • There is no evidence that favipiravir reduces mortality. It reduces duration of hospital stay in non-severe cases
  • Recently, WHO recommended against the use of remdesivir in hospitalized patients, regardless of the severity, as there is no evidence that it improves survival

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A Gram stain smear is prepared from the discharge sample, revealing numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes with intracellular gram-negative diplococci. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Explanation:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonococcal urethritis. It is identified on Gram stain by its characteristic intracellular gram-negative diplococci within neutrophils, making it the most likely causative organism in this case.

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae:

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded).

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

Incorrect Options:

Trichomonas (Option A): Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan that causes urethritis and vaginitis, but it does not appear on Gram stain as gram-negative diplococci. Instead, it is diagnosed using wet mount microscopy, where motile trophozoites with flagella are seen.

Chlamydia trachomatis (Option B): Chlamydia trachomatis is an intracellular bacterium that causes non-gonococcal urethritis. It does not stain well with Gram stain due to its intracellular nature and lack of a peptidoglycan cell wall. Instead, it is diagnosed using NAAT (nucleic acid amplification testing).

Gardnerella (Option D): Gardnerella vaginalis is a facultative anaerobic gram-variable rod associated with bacterial vaginosis. It is not a common cause of male urethral discharge and does not appear as gram-negative diplococci.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is not involved in the action of oral contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increase GnRH release

Explanation:

Oral contraceptives, particularly combination hormonal contraceptives (CHCs), work through the following mechanisms:

  • Inhibition of Ovulation (Option C): The estrogen and progestin components suppress gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion from the hypothalamus. This leads to reduced release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) by the pituitary, preventing ovulation.
  • Thickening of Cervical Mucus (Option B): Progestin increases the viscosity of cervical mucus, creating a barrier that impedes sperm entry into the uterus.
  • Endometrial Alteration: Hormonal changes modify the uterine lining, making it unsuitable for implantation (Option A).

An increase in GnRH release would stimulate the pituitary to produce FSH and LH, promoting ovulation rather than suppressing it. Since this contradicts the mechanism of action of oral contraceptives, Option D is correct as it does not align with their effects.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout?

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID

choices.text: Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAIDC & D

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - A, B & C:

  • Aspirin is generally avoided in the treatment of gout because it can interfere with uric acid excretion, potentially exacerbating the condition.
  • It competes with uric acid for renal secretion, reducing uric acid elimination and increasing the risk of accumulation.
  • The DOC in acute attack of gout:
    • First-line: NSAIDs (all except aspirin and paracetamol)
      • E.g. Naproxen, piroxicam, diclofenac, indomethacin, or etoricoxib
    • NSAID resistant cases: Colchicine
    • Colchicine resistant cases: Intra-articular corticosteroids

Diclofenac is an NSAID used to treat acute gout attacks. It tends to accumulate in inflamed joints, offering targeted relief from pain and inflammation.

Indomethacin is another NSAID frequently used to manage gout. It works by inhibiting the production of inflammatory substances like prostaglandins, helping to alleviate pain and inflammation associated with gout.

Drugs precipitating Gout:

  • Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
  • Aspirin (Low dose)
  • Niacin
  • Thiazide & Lasix
  • Ethambutol
  • Alcohol
  • Pyrazinamide

questions.text: What is the appropriate evaluation for a 30-year-old woman who visits an infertility clinic and has a consistent 28 day menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum progesterone day 21

Explanation:

  • In a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, the evaluation for ovulation can be done by measuring serum progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle. Day 21 corresponds to the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle when progesterone levels should be elevated if ovulation has occurred.

 

Day 14 corresponds to the expected time of ovulation in a woman with a regular 28-day cycle. Serum progesterone levels on day 14 (Option A) may not accurately reflect whether ovulation has occurred.

Serum luteinizing hormone (LH) levels surge just before ovulation. However, in a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, day 14 (Option C) may not correspond to the actual day of ovulation.

LH levels return to baseline after ovulation, so measuring serum LH on day 21 (Option D) may not provide accurate information about ovulation.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms belongs to the given life cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leptospira

Explanation:

  • Leptospira species are spirochetes responsible for leptospirosis. Their life cycle involves animal reservoirs, particularly rodents, which excrete the bacteria in urine. Humans acquire infection through exposure to contaminated water or soil, making this the correct answer.

 

Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

Incorrect Options:

Hantavirus (Option B): Hantavirus is transmitted via aerosolized rodent excreta, particularly urine and feces, but it does not have a distinct life cycle involving waterborne transmission like Leptospira. Instead, it primarily causes hantavirus pulmonary syndrome or hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome.

Yersinia pestis (Option C): Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is transmitted through flea bites and direct contact with infected animals. It does not involve a waterborne life cycle linked to urine contamination.

Salmonella typhi (Option D): Salmonella typhi causes typhoid fever and is transmitted via the fecal-oral route through contaminated food and water, not through urine-contaminated environments like Leptospira.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is a process that enhances the binding strength of antibodies to their specific antigen during an immune response. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Somatic hypermutation

Explanation:

  • Affinity maturation occurs due to somatic hypermutation, a process in which point mutations accumulate in the variable regions of immunoglobulin genes within germinal centers of lymphoid tissues. B cells with higher-affinity receptors are selectively expanded through antigen-driven selection, leading to progressively stronger antigen binding.

The formation of antibodies, or immunoglobulins involves multiple cellular components and steps:

  1. Antigen Encounter and Recognition
    • The process begins when B cells encounter a specific antigen. This antigen must be recognized as foreign to activate the adaptive immune response.
    • B cell receptors (BCRs) on the surface of B cells bind to the antigen. This recognition is highly specific and depends on the unique variable regions of the immunoglobulin on BCRs.
  2. Activation of B Cells
    • Upon binding with the antigen, B cells become activated, which requires help from T helper (Th) cells.
    • T cells are required to release cytokines and co-stimulatory signals, which aid in the full activation of B cells, especially in the case of protein antigens.
  3. Proliferation and Clonal Expansion
    • Activated B cells undergo clonal expansion, where they proliferate to create identical cells that can produce the same specific antibody.
    • This clonal expansion amplifies the immune response, ensuring that a sufficient number of cells are available to target the pathogen.
  4. Differentiation into Plasma Cells and Memory B Cells
    • Following expansion, B cells differentiate into two main cell types:
      • Plasma Cells: These are the effector cells that actively secrete antibodies. Plasma cells are responsible for producing large quantities of antibodies, which are then released into the bloodstream.
      • Memory B Cells: These cells are long-lived and retain the memory of the specific antigen. Upon subsequent exposure to the same antigen, memory B cells can quickly initiate a secondary immune response, leading to a faster and more robust production of antibodies.
  5. Antibody Class Switching
    • Initially, B cells produce IgM antibodies. However, with the help of Th cells, B cells can undergo a process called "class switching" to produce other types of antibodies like IgG, IgA, or IgE.
    • Class switching allows the immune system to adapt the type of antibody produced to the specific requirements of the immune response, depending on the nature of the pathogen and the location of the infection.
  6. Affinity Maturation
    • Affinity maturation occurs in the germinal centers of lymphoid tissues and involves the somatic hypermutation of antibody genes.
    • This process leads to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for the antigen, allowing for a more effective immune response.
  7. Memory and Long-Term Immunity
    • Memory B cells generated during the primary response ensure long-term immunity. If the same antigen is encountered again, these cells quickly respond by differentiating into plasma cells and producing antibodies.
    • This secondary immune response is usually faster and more intense due to the Spresence of these memory cells.


Incorrect Options:

Isotype switching (Option A): Isotype switching (class switching) involves changes in the constant region of the immunoglobulin heavy chain, altering the antibody's effector function but not its antigen-binding affinity. It does not contribute to affinity maturation.

mRNA splicing (Option C): mRNA splicing is a post-transcriptional process that removes introns and joins exons in RNA molecules. While it is essential for immunoglobulin expression (e.g., determining membrane-bound vs. secreted antibody forms), it does not influence affinity maturation.

VDJ rearrangement (Option D): VDJ recombination generates the initial diversity of the B-cell receptor before antigen exposure. However, affinity maturation occurs later, after antigen stimulation, through somatic hypermutation and selection in germinal centers.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following structures is responsible for the watery diarrhea seen in cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zonula occludens

Explanation:

  • Zonula occludens, also known as tight junctions, maintain the selective permeability of the intestinal epithelium.
  • Cholera toxin binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells. Once internalized, the A subunit of the toxin activates adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP disrupts ion transport, causing a significant efflux of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in profuse watery diarrhea.

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea.
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Incorrect Options:

Intercalated discs (Option A): Intercalated discs are specialized junctions in cardiac muscle that facilitate electrical and mechanical coupling between cardiomyocytes. They are not involved in intestinal permeability or cholera-induced diarrhea.

Macula densa (Option B): The macula densa is a group of specialized epithelial cells in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney involved in regulating blood pressure and sodium balance. It does not play a role in cholera pathophysiology.

Hemidesmosomes (Option D): Hemidesmosomes anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane and are involved in structural integrity rather than regulating paracellular transport or fluid secretion.

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved in its transmission.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trombiculid mite

Explanation:

  • Trombiculid mites (chigger mites) are the vectors for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Incorrect Options:

Hard tick (Option A): Hard ticks (Ixodidae) are vectors for diseases like Lyme disease (Borrelia burgdorferi), babesiosis, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever. However, they are not the primary vectors for organisms transmitted by trombiculid mites.

Soft tick (Option B): Soft ticks (Argasidae) primarily transmit Borrelia species responsible for tick-borne relapsing fever. They do not play a role in the transmission of pathogens associated with trombiculid mites.

Louse (Option D): Lice are involved in transmitting Rickettsia prowazekii (epidemic typhus), Bartonella quintana (trench fever), and Borrelia recurrentis (louse-borne relapsing fever), but they are not involved in the transmission of scrub typhus.

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervix is favorable. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Suction and evacuation

Explanation:

The clinical presentation with vaginal bleeding, a favorable cervix and the ultrasound findings of a snowstorm appearance are highly suggestive of a complete or partial molar pregnancy.

  • The patient comes under Group A, where the cervix is favorable. The recommended management includes suction and evacuation.
  • A negative pressure of 200–250 mm Hg is applied during the procedure, which is usually performed under diazepam sedation or general anesthesia.

The next best step in management for this condition is suction and evacuation (also known as dilatation and curettage) to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.

 

Medical management (Option A) is not appropriate in the case of a molar pregnancy. Molar pregnancies require the complete removal of the abnormal tissue.

While beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG) levels (Option B) are used to monitor the response to treatment in molar pregnancies, the immediate management in this scenario is to evacuate the uterus due to the risk of complications associated with molar pregnancies.

Hysterectomy (Option D) is not the initial management for a molar pregnancy. Conservative management with suction and evacuation is the preferred approach unless there are specific indications for hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L1

Explanation:

  • The HPV vaccine is made using recombinant L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles (VLPs) that mimic the HPV outer capsid. These VLPs elicit a strong immune response without containing viral genetic material, making the vaccine safe and effective.

Vaccine Name

Cervavac (HPV4)

Gardasil 4 (HPV4)

Gardasil 9 (HPV9)

Strain Number

4

4

9

L1 protein of Virus-like particles

6, 11, 16, 18

6, 11, 16, 18

6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 35, 45, 52, 58

Target Age (Girls)

9–26 years

9–45 years

9–45 years

Target Age (Boys)

9-26 years

9–26 years

9–45 years

Dose (Age < 15)

2 doses

Dose (Age ≥ 15)

3 doses

Schedule

(Age < 15)

0, 6–12 months

Schedule

(Age ≥ 15)

0, 2, 6 months

Dosage & Route

0.5 mL, intramuscular

Injection Site

Upper arm (deltoid)

National Program

In certain states for girls aged 11–13 years.

IAP 2021

All young girls are recommended. (and boys in Cervavac)

Catch-up Coverage

Up to 45 years (preferably pre-sexual activity) in Gardasil 4 & 9.

Only up to 26 years in Cervavac.

Side Effects

Local pain, swelling, erythema, fever, syncope (due to injection, not vaccine)

C/I

Anaphylaxis after the previous dose.

Storage

2–8°C, protect from light.

Note:

  • Cervavac (HPV4) is licensed and recommended for both girls and boys in India, according to the recent guidelines by The Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) as of January 2024.
  • Cervarix (HPV2), on the other hand, was used previously and only licensed and recommended for girls in India, and not for boys.

Incorrect Options:

E6 & E7 (Option A): E6 and E7 are oncogenic proteins of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) that play a role in carcinogenesis by inactivating tumor suppressor proteins (p53 and Rb, respectively). These are not included in the HPV vaccine, as their presence could pose a risk of oncogenic transformation.

E1 & E2 (Option C): E1 and E2 are early proteins involved in HPV DNA replication and transcriptional regulation. They are not components of the HPV vaccine.

L2 (Option D): L2 is another capsid protein, but the HPV vaccine primarily uses the L1 protein to induce an immune response.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not cut in a mediolateral episiotomy?

choices.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Obturator muscle

Explanation:

  • Obturator muscle is not cut during mediolateral episiotomy. Whereas all other muscles in given options are cut during mediolateral episiotomy.

Episiotomy:

  • Episiotomy surgically planned incision on the perineum and posterior vaginal wall performed during the second stage of labor (ideally performed just before crowning) to enlarge the vaginal introitus for easier and safer delivery and also to prevent overstretching and rupture of perineal muscles. This is considered a second-degree perineal injury.

Indications:

  • Rigid perineum
  • Anticipating perineal tear (big baby, face-to-pubis delivery, breech, shoulder dystocia)
  • Operative delivery
  • Previous perineal surgery

Types of episiotomy:

Type

Advantages

Disadvantages

Mediolateral

(most prevalent)
  • Reduced risk of severe perineal tears.
  • May facilitate easier delivery.
  • Less risk of injury to the anal sphincter compared to the midline.
  • Higher risk of postpartum pain and discomfort.
  • Potential for increased blood loss compared to other types.

Median
  • Simplicity in execution.
  • Less postoperative pain compared to mediolateral.
  • Higher risk of severe perineal tears, including anal sphincter injury.
  • Potential for increased healing time and complications due to midline orientation.

Structures cut mediolateral episiotomy:

From outer to inner:

  • Skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves (Option D).
  • Facia covering the muscles that are cut.
  • Muscles
    • Levator ani.
    • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles (Option A).
    • Bulbospongiosus (Option C).
  • Posterior vaginal wall

 

Steps of mediolateral episiotomy:

questions.text: What criteria are utilized for the diagnosis of abdominal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Studdiford criteria

Explanation:

  • Abdominal pregnancy refers to the implantation of a fertilized egg outside the uterus in the abdominal cavity. It is a rare and potentially life-threatening condition. The diagnosis of abdominal pregnancy can be challenging due to its rarity and varied clinical presentations. However, certain criteria have been established to aid in its diagnosis.

The Studdiford criteria are a set of criteria used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy. These criteria include:

  • Absence of uterine pathology: The absence of any uterine abnormality that could explain the ectopic pregnancy, such as uterine rupture or previous uterine surgery.
  • Demonstration of a live fetus or placental tissue within the abdomen: This can be confirmed through imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI, which show the presence of the fetus or placenta outside the uterus.
  • The fetus or placenta being separate from other abdominal organs: The fetus or placenta is not attached to any other abdominal organ and can be clearly differentiated from surrounding structures.

 

The Spiegelberg criteria (Option A) are used for diagnosing tubal ectopic pregnancy, not abdominal pregnancy.

The Rubin criteria (Option B) are also used for diagnosing tubal ectopic pregnancy, not abdominal pregnancy.

The term "ring of fire" (Option D) is not a recognized criterion for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy. It may refer to the sensation of burning or intense pain felt during childbirth, particularly during the crowning stage.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and chills. Throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over the tonsils. Albert staining is ordered. What are the constituents of Albert’s stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Toluidine blue and malachite green

Explanation:

  • Albert's stain causes the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae to appear bluish-purple upon staining.

Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2
  • Iodine
  • Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules.

Procedure:

  • Stain the smear with Albert I stain, then drain and wash it
  • Apply Albert II stain to cover the smear, then drain it

Application:

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes, characterized by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli
  • Albert's, Neisser's, and Ponder's stains help stain these distinctive granules in the bacteria
  • These granules are also Found in Spirillum, Gardnerella, Yersinia pestis, yeast, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB)

Incorrect Optioins:

Carbol fuchsin and methylene blue (Option B): This combination is used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining for acid-fast bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Carbol fuchsin and malachite green (Option C): Carbol fuchsin is used for acid-fast staining, while malachite green is commonly used in spore staining (e.g., Schaeffer-Fulton method).

Toluidine blue and methylene blue (Option D): While Toluidine blue is a component of Albert’s stain, methylene blue is not. Methylene blue is used in Loeffler’s methylene blue stain.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, who develops blisters on areas of friction, with a history of a previous child having similar complaints and dying at 2 weeks of age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Epidermolysis bullosa

  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of inherited disorders characterized by the formation of blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes in response to minor trauma or friction.
  • It is caused by defects in the proteins that help anchor the layers of the skin together.
  • The fact that the baby's previous sibling had similar complaints and died at a young age further supports the diagnosis of a genetic disorder like EB, as it is an inherited condition.
  • It has four main types: EB simplex, junctional EB, dystrophic EB, and Kindler syndrome.

Pathophysiology

  • Caused by mutations in genes encoding skin structural proteins (keratins, laminins, collagen).
  • Leads to weakened dermal-epidermal adhesion, resulting in blister formation with minor friction or trauma.

Features

  • Fragile skin with fluid-filled blisters, erosions, and scarring.
  • Mucosal involvement (oral, esophageal, ocular, and genitourinary).
  • Severe forms can lead to deformities, malnutrition, and infections.
  • Dystrophic EB may cause mitten-hand deformities due to fusion of digits.

Investigations & Diagnosis

  • Skin biopsy with immunofluorescence mapping – Identifies the defective protein.
  • Genetic testing – Confirms mutation type.
  • Electron microscopy – Assesses ultrastructural defects.

Classification and Antigen

 

Disease

Target antigens

Bullous pemphigoid

BP 180, BP 230

Pemphigoid gestationis

BP 180, BP 230

Linear IgA bullous dermatosis (LABD)

BP 180 (LAD1)

Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

Collagen VII

Bullous lupus erythematosus

Collagen VII

Cicatricial pemphigoid

BP 180, laminin, α4 and β6 subunits of integrin

MMP (Mucous Membrane Pemphigoid)

BP 180, laminin 332

Linear IgA

LAD1

DH (Dermatitis Herpetiformis)

Epidermal Transglutaminase (not from basement membrane)

Incorrect Options:

Chronic bullous disorder of childhood (Option B): This condition is characterized by recurrent blistering and typically occurs in older children, not in infancy.

Congenital syphilis (Option C): While syphilis can cause skin manifestations, it typically presents with other symptoms as well and can be confirmed through specific diagnostic tests.

Neonatal pemphigus (Option D): Neonatal pemphigus is a rare autoimmune condition in which autoantibodies are transferred from the mother to the baby, resulting in blistering.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Ebola virus is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transmitted by mosquito

Explanation:

Ebola virus is not transmitted by mosquitoes. Instead, it spreads through direct contact with infected bodily fluids (blood, saliva, vomit, feces, sweat, urine, breast milk, or semen) of symptomatic individuals or contaminated surfaces.

Incorrect Options:

It is a filovirus (Option A): Ebola virus belongs to the Filoviridae family, which also includes Marburg virus. Filoviruses are filamentous, enveloped, negative-sense RNA viruses that cause severe hemorrhagic fever.

Bats act as a reservoir (Option C): Fruit bats (Pteropodidae family) are believed to be the natural reservoirs of the Ebola virus, maintaining the virus in wildlife populations and occasionally transmitting it to other animals or humans.

Human-to-human transmission is seen (Option D): Ebola virus spreads between humans through direct contact with infected bodily fluids or contaminated objects. Healthcare workers and caregivers are at high risk if proper protective measures are not followed.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is employed to measure the viral load?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Real-time RT-PCR

Explanation:

Real-time Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) is the gold standard for measuring viral load, especially for RNA viruses like HIV, SARS-CoV-2, and HCV. It quantifies viral RNA in real-time, providing an accurate measure of infection severity and treatment response.

  • Real-time PCR, also known as quantitative PCR (qPCR), provides the advantage of quantifying DNA or RNA as the amplification process occurs in real time.
  • This is achieved by measuring the fluorescence emitted by DNA-binding dyes or probes that are incorporated during the PCR amplification.
  • Traditional PCR only allows for the detection of the PCR product at the end of the process, without the capability to quantify the initial amount of target nucleic acid.

Uses of Real-Time PCR:

  • Gene Expression Analysis
  • Quantification of DNA or RNA
  • Detection of Pathogens
  • Genotyping
  • Cancer Research
  • Forensic Analysis
  • Biotechnology Applications

Incorrect Options:

ELISA (Option A): Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) detects viral antigens or antibodies but does not quantify viral RNA or DNA. It is commonly used for screening infections like HIV and hepatitis but is not suitable for viral load measurement.

Western Blot (Option B): Western blot is a confirmatory test for detecting specific viral proteins, such as in HIV diagnosis. However, it does not quantify viral genetic material, making it unsuitable for viral load assessment.

Immunoelectrophoresis (Option D): Immunoelectrophoresis is used to separate and identify proteins (e.g., immunoglobulins in multiple myeloma) but does not measure viral load.

questions.text: A school-going child who had applied henna comes to dermatology OPD with the following lesions. Her mother also complains that she has a habit of scratching her hand whenever she is studying. What is the diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dermatitis artefacta

  • Dermatitis artefacta is a condition characterized by self-inflicted skin lesions, consciously or unconsciously caused by the individual. It is considered a psychiatric disorder rather than a primary skin disease.
  • The lesions in dermatitis artefacta often have unusual or bizarre patterns and may not follow the typical distribution or characteristics of known dermatological conditions.
  • These lesions may appear in unusual shapes, patterns, or locations that are not consistent with typical henna reactions or allergic contact dermatitis.
  • Treatment involves a multidisciplinary approach involving dermatologists, psychologists, and psychiatrists to address the underlying psychological issues and provide appropriate care and support to the individual.
  • In the case of henna application, if the child deliberately scratches or traumatizes the skin in the area where henna was applied, it can result in skin lesions that resemble a dermatitis reaction. The child may create patterns or designs by scratching the skin, leading to the appearance of lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Contact dermatitis due to henna (Option A): Could be a possible differential diagnosis, as henna can sometimes cause an allergic reaction in certain individuals. However, in this case, the option "dermatitis artefacta" suggests that the lesions are self-induced rather than a true allergic contact dermatitis.

Polymorphous light eruption (Option C): (PMLE) is a type of photodermatitis that occurs in response to exposure to sunlight or artificial ultraviolet (UV) light. However, the given information about henna application does not align with the characteristic triggers of PMLE.

Vitiligo (Option D): Vitiligo is an autoimmune disorder and does not involve the intentional or self-inflicted creation of skin lesions.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with a swollen, red knee joint that is tender to touch. Two weeks prior, he had an episode of fever with bloody diarrhea. Which of the following could be the possible organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Shigella

Explanation:

  • Shigella species, particularly Shigella flexneri, can trigger reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) in genetically susceptible individuals (especially those with HLA-B27). The arthritis typically develops 1-3 weeks after the initial infection and involves large joints like the knee.

Shigella

Features of Shigella
  • Pathogenic Species
    • Shigella dysenteriae
    • Shigella flexneri
    • Shigella boydii
    • Shigella sonnei
  • Transmission
    • Primarily via the fecal-oral route.
    • Commonly spread through contaminated food and water or direct person-to-person contact.
  • Infective Dose
    • Very low; as few as 10-100 bacteria can cause infection.
  • Invasion
    • Invades and multiplies within colonic epithelial cells, leading to cell death and inflammation.

Clinical Presentation of Shigella:
  • Diarrhea:
    • Typically acute and often bloody (dysentery).
    • Incubation Period: 1-3 days after exposure.
    • Prodromal Period: 1-2 days after the incubation period.
  • Abdominal Pain:
    • Severe cramping.
  • Fever:
    • Often high-grade.
  • Tenesmus:
    • Painful straining with defecation.
  • Systemic Symptoms:
    • Malaise, headache, and sometimes vomiting.
  • Complications
    • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): Particularly associated with Shigella dysenteriae type 1.
    • Reactive Arthritis: More commonly seen after infection with Shigella flexneri.
    • Neurological Complications: Including seizures, especially in young children.

Diagnosis

Clinical Evaluation:

  • Based on symptoms such as bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever, along with a recent history of exposure (e.g., travel to endemic areas).

Laboratory Tests:

  • Stool Culture: Gold standard for diagnosis; Shigella species identified on selective media like MacConkey agar or XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar.
  • Biochemical Tests: Confirmatory tests include lactose non-fermentation and indole production, among other specific biochemical characteristics.
  • Serotyping: Identification of specific Shigella species and serotypes using agglutination tests with specific antisera.
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Rapid detection of Shigella-specific genes and virulence factors.
  • Stool Microscopy: Presence of leukocytes and erythrocytes in stool samples indicative of invasive diarrhea.

Treatment

Fluid Replacement:

  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT): Recommended for mild to moderate dehydration.
  • Intravenous Fluids: Necessary for severe dehydration or if the patient cannot tolerate oral fluids.

Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Recommended for severe cases, young children, the elderly, and immunocompromised patients.
  • First-line Antibiotics: Include fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone), or azithromycin based on susceptibility testing.
  • Increasing antibiotic resistance necessitates periodic updates on local resistance patterns.

Symptomatic Treatment:

  • Antipyretics for managing fever.
  • Avoidance of antimotility agents like loperamide, which can worsen the infection.

Incorrect Options:

E. coli (Option A): Certain E. coli strains, particularly Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC and Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC), can cause bloody diarrhea. However, E. coli is not a common trigger for reactive arthritis, which is a post-infectious immune-mediated condition affecting joints.

Giardia (Option C): Giardia lamblia causes non-bloody, watery diarrhea due to malabsorption but does not typically trigger reactive arthritis.

Rotavirus (Option D): Rotavirus is a leading cause of viral gastroenteritis in children, causing watery diarrhea and dehydration, but it does not cause bloody diarrhea or reactive arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following options is not suitable for the treatment of PCOD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ulipristal

Explanation:

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a hormonal disorder characterized by hormonal imbalances, irregular menstrual cycles, and the formation of small cysts on the ovaries. The treatment of PCOS aims to manage the symptoms and restore hormonal balance.
  • Ulipristal is an emergency contraceptive pill that is used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex or after the failure of another birth control method. It works by preventing or delaying ovulation.

 

Clomiphene citrate (Option A) is a medication commonly used for the treatment of PCOS. It works by stimulating ovulation, making it useful for women with PCOS who are trying to conceive.

Letrozole (Option B) is another medication often used for inducing ovulation in women with PCOS. It is an aromatase inhibitor that helps regulate estrogen levels and promote ovulation.

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (Option D) is a surgical procedure used to treat PCOS in cases where medication has not been effective or well-tolerated. It involves making small punctures or using a laser or electrical current to destroy a small portion of the ovarian tissue, which can help restore ovulation and improve fertility.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Preservative

  • Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is commonly used as a preservative in cosmetics. It helps prevent the growth of bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms in cosmetic products, thereby extending their shelf life and maintaining their safety and efficacy.

Incorrect Options:

Surfactant (Option A): Surfactants are commonly used in cosmetic products to enhance foaming, cleansing, and emulsifying properties. While surfactants are frequently used in cosmetics, methylisothiazolinone is not primarily used as a surfactant.

Humectant (Option B): Humectants are commonly used in skincare and cosmetic products to prevent dryness and maintain moisture balance. Methylisothiazolinone is not typically used as a humectant.

Emulsifier (Option C): Emulsifiers are commonly used in cosmetic formulations to create stable emulsions, such as creams and lotions. Methylisothiazolinone is not primarily used as an emulsifier.

questions.text: Which of the following is excluded from the components of the Bishop score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type of maternal pelvis

Explanation:

  • Bishop score focuses specifically on assessing cervical factors to determine the readiness for labor induction or predict the likelihood of spontaneous labor.
  • The score does not take into account the type of maternal pelvis, as the primary goal is to evaluate cervical characteristics.

 

Cervical length (Option A) is a component of the Bishop score. Cervical length is assessed using ultrasound and is an important factor in determining cervical readiness. A shorter cervix is associated with higher chances of successful labor induction or progression of labor.

Cervical position (Option C) is another component of the Bishop score. The position of the cervix is evaluated through palpation during a pelvic examination. A more anterior and easily palpable cervix is considered favorable for labor.

Dilatation of cervix (Option D) is also a component of the Bishop score. The degree of cervical dilatation is assessed during a pelvic examination. The Bishop score assigns a score from 0 to 3 based on the extent of cervical dilatation, with higher scores indicating greater dilatation.

questions.text: Which of these options does not show symptoms of a maculopapular rash?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Zoster (shingles)

  • Zoster, commonly known as shingles, presents with a different type of rash called a vesicular rash. The rash is characterized by fluid-filled blisters (vesicles) that are localized to a specific area of the body and follow the distribution of a nerve.

A maculopapular rash can be seen in various conditions, including:

  • Rubella (German measles)
  • Measles (Rubeola)
