  • Fifth disease (Erythema infectiosum)
  • Roseola (Sixth disease)
  • Drug reactions: Certain medications can cause a maculopapular rash as an adverse reaction.

Incorrect Options:

Rubella (Option B): Rubella infection typically presents with a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

Dengue (Option C): During the febrile phase of dengue fever, patients may develop a maculopapular rash.

Measles (Option D): Measles infection is associated with a maculopapular rash that usually starts on the face and spreads downward to the rest of the body. The rashmay be accompanied by other symptoms such as cough, fever, and conjunctivitis.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the condition affecting the hair, resulting in the following appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Trichothiodystrophy

Trichothiodystrophy is a rare genetic disorder that affects the structure of the hair.

One of the characteristic features of Trichothiodystrophy is the presence of "tiger tail banding" when the hair is examined under polarized light microscopy. This term refers to alternating light and dark bands along the hair shaft, resembling the pattern of a tiger's tail.

  • Trichothiodystrophy is primarily characterized by brittle hair that is prone to breakage and has a characteristic appearance under the microscope.
  • Some key features of Trichothiodystrophy include:
    • Brittle Hair
    • Tiger Tail Banding
    • Variable Hair Color
    • Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities
    • Additional features may include dry and scaly skin, brittle nails, photosensitivity (sensitivity to sunlight), and ocular abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Trichorhexis nodosa (Option A): Trichorhexis nodosa is a hair shaft disorder characterized by nodules or nodes along the hair shaft. It does not typically show the specific "tiger tail banding" pattern seen in Trichothiodystrophy.

Trichorexis invaginata (Option B): Trichorexis invaginata, also known as "bamboo hair," is a condition in which the hair shaft is characterized by multiple invaginations or nodules. It does not present with the specific banding pattern seen in Trichothiodystrophy.

Monilethrix (Option D): Monilethrix is a hereditary hair disorder characterized by beaded hair shafts that resemble a necklace. It does not show the specific "tiger tail banding" pattern seen in Trichothiodystrophy.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected and processed for examination. The specimen is labeled at different levels as I, II, III, and IV. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IV

Explanation:

Parasitic ova are definitively observed under a microscope at the final processed level, after appropriate concentration and staining techniques such as formalin-ethyl acetate sedimentation.

  • Level IV, bottom of the tube, contains protozoan cyst and ova.

sedimentation technique labelled" data-author="" data-hash="12366" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="593" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/uEO0ImuI5vUegVqMl1KS1746621226.png" width="458" />

Sedimentation technique

Sedimentation techniques and Flotation techniques are concentration techniques used to recover low numbers of parasites in stool samples.

  • Useful for epidemiological studies and assessing treatment response.
  • Detects eggs, cysts, and larvae but does not detect trophozoites, as these get destroyed in the process.
  • Sedimentation techniques:
    • Eggs and cysts settle at the bottom due to higher density.
    • Example: Formalin-ether concentration increases detection sensitivity by 8–10 times.
  • Flotation techniques:
    • Specimens are suspended in a denser medium (e.g., saturated salt solution) in which the eggs and cysts float.
    • Limitations: Cannot concentrate non-floating parasites (e.g., unfertilized Ascaris eggs).

questions.text: Identify the type of skin lesion:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Annular

  • The correct option is "annular." An annular skin lesion refers to a ring-shaped lesion with a clear or normal-looking center. It typically has a raised border or edge. This pattern is commonly seen in conditions such as ringworm (tinea corporis), granuloma annulare, and erythema migrans (associated with Lyme disease).

Some other types of skin lesions:

Skin Lesion

Description

Examples

Macule

Flat, discolored spot on the skin with no palpable elevation or depression.

Freckles, flat moles

Patch

Large, flat, maculopapular area of skin discoloration.

Vitiligo, café-au-lait spots

Papule

Small, solid, elevated lesion with a palpable surface.

Acne, warts

Plaque

Elevated, flat-topped lesion with a broad, flat surface.

Psoriasis plaques, seborrheic keratosis

Vesicle

Small, fluid-filled blister, usually less than 5mm in diameter.

Chickenpox blisters, herpes simplex

Bulla

Large, fluid-filled blister, typically more than 5mm in diameter.

Bullous pemphigoid, second-degree burns

Pustule

Small, elevated lesion filled with pus.

Acne pustules, impetigo

Wheal

Transient, raised, and edematous lesion with irregular borders, often associated with itching or allergic reactions.

Insect bite reactions, hives (urticaria)

Nodule

Solid, palpable lesion, often deeper in the skin layers.

Dermatofibroma, lipoma

Tumor

Solid, elevated lesion larger than a few centimeters in diameter.

Basal cell carcinoma, melanoma

Plaque

Large, flat, elevated lesion with a flat surface and a diameter greater than its height.

Psoriasis plaques, lichen planus

Burrow

Linear or serpignious tunnel in the skin caused by infestation or burrowing of parasites.

Scabies burrows

Scale

Dry, flaky, or thickened skin with shedding of dead skin cells.

Psoriasis scales, seborrheic dermatitis

Crust

Dried exudate or secretion on the skin surface.

Impetigo crusts, dried blood crusts

Erosion

Loss of the superficial epidermis, resulting in a moist, shallow depression.

Aphthous ulcers, erosion due to scratching

Ulcer

Loss of the entire epidermis and at least part of the dermis, resulting in a deep, open lesion.

Pressure ulcers, venous ulcers

Fissure

Linear crack or slit-like split in the skin.

Athlete's foot fissures, anal fissures

Scar

Fibrous tissue that replaces normal skin after injury or surgery.

Surgical scars, keloids

Atrophy

Thinning or depression of the skin with loss of normal skin markings.

Striae (stretch marks), aged skin

Incorrect Options:

Nummular lesions (Option A): These are coin-shaped or circular lesions with distinct borders and a flat or slightly elevated surface. They are usually smaller and do not have the characteristic ring shape.

Discoid lesions (Option C): These are circular or oval-shaped lesions with well-defined borders, but they do not necessarily have a ring shape or central clearing.

Target lesions (Option D): Target or "bull's eye" lesions have concentric rings or circles of different colors. They typically have three zones—an outer ring, an intermediate ring, and a central clearing. This pattern is seen in conditions such as erythema multiforme and Lyme disease.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago presents with diarrhea for 9 days. A stool sample subjected to Kinyoun stain reveals 4-6 μm structures. Which of the following is true about the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sporozoites adhere to intestinal mucosa

Explanation:

  • The organism described is Cryptosporidium, which exhibits autoinfection due to thin-walled oocysts that do not exit the host and instead continue the infection cycle, contributing to chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. (Option A ruled out)
  • After ingestion, the sporozoites excyst from oocysts in the small intestine and attach to the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to malabsorption, secretory diarrhea, and epithelial damage.

Life Cycle of Cryptosporidium

1. Ingestion of Infective Oocysts: Humans or animals ingest fully mature (sporulated) oocysts from contaminated water, food, or surfaces.

2. Excystation: In the host’s small intestine, the oocyst releases four sporozoites, which then attach to the intestinal epithelial cells.

3. Trophozoite Formation: The sporozoites develop into trophozoites within parasitophorous vacuoles (specialised compartments) in the brush border of the host’s intestinal cells.

4. Asexual Reproduction (Schizogony): Trophozoites undergo asexual reproduction to form type I meronts, each containing eight merozoites.

5. Release of Merozoites: The merozoites are released, infect new epithelial cells, and may undergo schizogony again to form more type I meronts or transition into type II meronts.

6. Sexual Reproduction (Gametogony): Type II meronts release merozoites that invade cells and begin the sexual phase, differentiating into microgametes (male) and macrogametes (female).

7. Fertilization and Oocyst Formation: The microgamete fertilises the macrogamete, forming a zygote that then develops into an oocyst.

8. Sporulation: The zygote undergoes sporogony to form a fully mature, sporulated oocyst containing four sporozoites.

9. Release of Oocysts: Two types of oocysts are produced:

  • Thick-walled oocysts: Excreted in faeces, they are mature and infective and transmit the infection to new hosts.
  • Thin-walled oocysts: Remain in the intestine and cause autoinfection, maintaining the cycle within the same host.

10. Transmission: Thick-walled oocysts are released into the environment through faeces, where they can infect new hosts upon ingestion.

Both sexual and asexual reproduction occurs within one host

Sporozoites are the infective form (Option B): The oocyst is the infective form of Cryptosporidium, not the sporozoite. The oocyst releases four sporozoites, which invade intestinal epithelial cells.

High infectivity dose is required (Option D): Cryptosporidium has a low infectious dose; as few as 10-30 oocysts can cause infection, making it highly transmissible.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test used to identify allergic contact dermatitis which is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction caused by external substances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Patch test

  • The patch test is a commonly used diagnostic tool for identifying the causative allergens in allergic contact dermatitis.
  • It involves applying small amounts of suspected allergens onto adhesive patches, which are then placed on the patient's skin (usually on the back). The patches remain in place for 48-72 hours.
  • The presence of erythema, vesiculation, or induration at the site of patch application indicates a positive reaction, suggesting sensitivity to the tested allergen.

Test Name

Method

Type of Allergy Detected

Skin Prick Test (SPT)

Small amounts of allergens are pricked into the skin

IgE-mediated (e.g., pollen, food, dust mites)

Intradermal Test

Allergen injected into the dermis

Drug, venom, or weak SPT allergens

Patch Test

Allergens applied on a patch and placed on skin

Contact dermatitis (e.g., metals, chemicals)

Serum IgE Test (RAST)

Measures allergen-specific IgE in blood

Food, environmental, drug allergies

 

Incorrect Options:

Radioimmunosorbent (RAST) (Option B): The RAST test is a blood test used to measure specific IgE antibodies in the serum. Allergic contact dermatitis is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T-cells, and it does not involve IgE antibodies. Therefore, the RAST test is not appropriate for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis.

Eosin-5′-maleimide binding test (Option C): The eosin-5′-maleimide binding test is a laboratory test used to assess the presence of hereditary spherocytosis, a congenital hemolytic anemia. It is not relevant for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis.

Nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test (Option D): It is primarily used in the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease, an inherited disorder characterized by defective neutrophil function. This test is not related to the diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for the condition resulting in the formation of blisters beneath the epidermis, where neutrophils are found at the tips of the dermal papillae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dapsone

  • Dapsone is the treatment of choice for sub-epidermal blister formation with neutrophils located at the tips of the dermal papillae.
  • This presentation is characteristic of a group of autoimmune blistering diseases known as subepidermal autoimmune bullous diseases, which include bullous pemphigoid and dermatitis herpetiformis.

Mechanism of Action of Dapsone

  • Inhibits neutrophil chemotaxis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, reducing blister formation.
  • Suppresses inflammatory mediators, leading to decreased skin damage.

Indications in Subepidermal Autoimmune Bullous Diseases

  • Dermatitis Herpetiformis (DH) – First-line treatment
  • Linear IgA Bullous Dermatosis (LABD) – Effective in most cases
  • Bullous Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (BSLE) – Used in resistant cases
  • Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA) – Occasionally used as adjunct therapy

 

Incorrect Options:

Rituximab (Option A): Rituximab is not the treatment of choice for sub-epidermal blister formation with neutrophils located at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Cyclosporine (Option C): Cyclosporine can be effective in managing certain blistering diseases, it is not the treatment of choice

Azathioprine (Option D): Azathioprine may be beneficial in some cases of autoimmune blistering diseases, it is not the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Antibody testing for SARS-CoV-2 depends upon which of the following factors?

choices.text: That the patient is in the window period

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Time of incubation

Explanation:

  • Antibody testing relies on the host's immune response, which takes time to develop.
  • IgM antibodies appear around 7–10 days after infection, while IgG antibodies become detectable after 2–3 weeks, peaking in the convalescent phase.
  • Thus, the timing of testing relative to symptom onset is critical.

Incorrect Options:

Presence of acute viral load (Option B): RT-PCR or antigen tests are used to detect acute viral load during early infection. Antibody tests do not detect active infection but indicate past exposure.

A high risk of reinfection (Option C): While waning immunity and viral mutations can contribute to reinfection, antibody testing does not directly assess reinfection risk.

That the patient is in the window period (Option D): The window period is the phase before detectable antibodies are produced. During this period, antibody tests may be falsely negative, making RT-PCR the preferred diagnostic method for early infection.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment approach for a known alcoholic patient who is brought to the emergency department in a disoriented state and complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lorazepam + thiamine

Explanation:

  • The patient is showing signs of alcohol withdrawal delirium (delirium tremens), including disorientation and visual hallucinations.
  • Delirium tremens is a severe withdrawal syndrome that occurs after sudden cessation of chronic alcohol consumption.
  • It is characterised by confusion, agitation, hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity and seizures.
  • The appropriate treatment includes benzodiazepines (lorazepam) for withdrawal symptoms and thiamine to prevent neurological complications like Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.

Alcohol Withdrawal management

Alcohol Withdrawal

Treatment

Mild or Moderate Withdrawal

 
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Short-acting (e.g., lorazepam) or long-acting (e.g., chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Carbamazepine (daily doses of 800 mg) is also effective and has minimal abuse liability.

Severe withdrawal

(Seizures)
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

Life threatening

(Delirium Tremens)

 
  • For extreme symptoms (delirium tremens or DTs), Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (e.g., 50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV).
  • Supportive care: High-calorie diet, multivitamins.
  • Thiamine: to avoid Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis. (Option B ruled out)
  • Haloperidol may be used for severe agitation but can lower the seizure threshold. (Option A and D ruled out)

Protracted Withdrawal:

Symptoms may last 2 to 6 months.
  • Acamprosate may help diminish some symptoms.
  • Cognitive and behavioural approaches are recommended.

questions.text:
Match the following parasites with their respective intermediate hosts:


	
		
			
			Parasite
			
			
			Host
			
		
		
			
			1. Diphyllobothrium
			
			
			a. Sheep
			
		
		
			
			2. Paragonimus
			
			
			b. Crab
			
		
		
			
			3. Brugia
			
			
			c. Cyclops
			
		
		
			
			4. Fasciola
			
			
			d. Mosquitoes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

Explanation:

Diphyllobothrium (Fish Tapeworm) → Cyclops

  • The first intermediate host is Cyclops (Copepod, a freshwater crustacean).
  • The second intermediate host is freshwater fish.
  • Humans acquire infection by consuming undercooked freshwater fish.

Paragonimus (Lung Fluke) → Crab

  • The first intermediate host is snail.
  • The second intermediate host is crabs or crayfish.
  • Humans acquire infection by consuming raw or undercooked crabs.

Brugia (Causes Lymphatic Filariasis) → Mosquitoes

  • Brugia malayi & Brugia timori are transmitted by mosquitoes (Mansonia, Anopheles, Aedes).
  • The mosquito serves as the intermediate host and vector.

Fasciola (Liver Fluke) → Sheep

  • The definitive host is sheep, cattle, or humans.
  • The intermediate host is aquatic snails.
  • Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated aquatic plants like watercress.

questions.text: What is the recommended medical approach for a psychotic patient who experiences voluntary aimless motions and has been observed standing motionless for extended periods with waxy flexibility and negativism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Lorazepam

  • The patient exhibits symptoms of catatonia, including voluntary aimless motions, prolonged immobility, waxy flexibility, and negativism.
  • Catatonia is a psychomotor syndrome often associated with psychiatric conditions like schizophrenia or mood disorders.
  • Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is the first-line treatment for catatonia.

Catatonia

Definition
  • It is a psychomotor syndrome characterised by a range of motor, behavioural, and verbal disturbances.
  • It can occur in various psychiatric, medical, and neurological conditions and may present with excessive motor activity or markedly reduced motor activity.

Features
  • Stupor
  • Catalepsy
  • Waxy flexibility
  • Mutism
  • Negativism
  • Posturing: Spontaneous maintenance of a rigid or bizarre posture.
  • Stereotypies: Repetitive, non-goal-directed movements (e.g., hand flapping or grimacing).
  • Mannerisms: repetitive, odd, purposeful movements.
  • Agitation
  • Echolalia or Echopraxia: Repetition of another's words (echolalia) or movements (echopraxia)

Treatment

  • First-line treatment involves benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam), which are effective in alleviating catatonic symptoms.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is also highly effective and often used in patients who do not respond to pharmacotherapy or when rapid resolution is required.

Haloperidol (Option A) is an antipsychotic medication that is used for psychosis, and it may be used in the management of psychotic features of catatonia as well. However, it is not the first-line treatment for catatonia, sometimes use of antipsychotics alone can worsen the catatonic symptoms.

Clonidine (Option C) is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that is used for managing hypertension and ADHD. It has no role in managing catatonia.

Propranolol (Option D) is a beta-blocker that is used for managing hypertension, anxiety, and essential tremors. It does not treat catatonia and has no effect on the underlying motor symptoms or psychotic features associated with this condition.

questions.text: What was the intended function of thiopentone and succinylcholine given to a patient receiving ECT treatment for severe depression?

choices.text: To induce anesthesia and relax muscles
To prevent memory loss after the ECT

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - To induce anesthesia and relax muscles

  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a procedure used to treat severe depression, and it involves the administration of a general anaesthetic and a muscle relaxant.
  • Thiopentone is an ultra-short-acting barbiturate that is used to induce anaesthesia, and Succinylcholine is a depolarising muscle relaxant that helps to prevent convulsions during the procedure.
  • However, methohexital is the most commonly used anaesthetic because of its lower likelihood of postictal arrhythmias and shorter duration of action.

To bring a calming effect (Option A): The purpose of ECT is not to sedate or calm the patient but to induce a controlled seizure in the brain for therapeutic effects.

To produce mood elevation (Option B): The primary goal of ECT is to treat severe psychiatric conditions (like depression, mania, or catatonia) by using controlled seizures to induce neurochemical changes that help improve the patient's mood over time. However, mood elevation is not the primary effect.

To prevent memory loss (Option D): The medications used during ECT are not intended to prevent memory loss. These drugs serve to induce anaesthesia and relax muscles, which help the patient remain unconscious and prevent muscle contractions during the induced seizure.

questions.text:
Match the following parasites with their respective organs of locomotion:


	
		
			
			Parasite
			
			
			Organ of Locomotion
			
		
		
			
			1. Balamuthia mandrillaris
			
			
			a. Flagella
			
		
		
			
			2. Balantidium coli
			
			
			b. Cilia
			
		
		
			
			3. Trichomonas vaginalis
			
			
			c. Pseudopod
			
		
		
			
			4. Toxoplasma gondii
			
			
			d. No particular organ
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

Explanation:

Balamuthia mandrillaris → Pseudopods

  • Free-living amoeba causing granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE).
  • Moves using pseudopods (temporary cytoplasmic projections).

Balantidium coli → Cilia

  • The only ciliated protozoan pathogenic to humans.
  • Causes balantidiasis (dysentery-like illness), often acquired from pigs.

Trichomonas vaginalis → Flagella

  • Pear-shaped protozoan with multiple flagella, responsible for trichomoniasis (STD).
  • No cyst stage (exists only in trophozoite form).

Toxoplasma gondii → No particular organ

  • An intracellular protozoan that moves via gliding motility (not a specific organ).
  • Causes toxoplasmosis, important in immunocompromised patients and pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following factors does not indicate a favourable prognosis for schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Insidious onset of symptoms

  • In schizophrenia, an insidious onset is typically associated with a worse prognosis.
  • It often reflects a more chronic course of the illness, with poorer long-term outcomes, as the symptoms develop slowly over time and can be harder to treat effectively.

Prognostic factors of Schizophrenia

Positive factors

Negative factors
  • Acute onset
  • Female sex
  • Living in a developed country
  • Presence of mood symptoms (Option D ruled out)
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • Married

 
  • Insidious onset
  • Childhood or adolescent onset
  • Poor premorbid functioning
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Absence of mood symptoms
  • Negative symptoms
  • Family History of schizophrenia
  • Single/ separated/ divorced

 

Positive symptoms (Option A) of schizophrenia include hallucinations, delusions, and disorganised thinking. These symptoms usually tend to respond better to treatment, especially with antipsychotic medications. Positive symptoms are typically associated with a better prognosis compared to negative symptoms, which usually contribute to a bad prognosis.

Late age of onset (Option B) of schizophrenia occurs after age 45 years of age, and it usually correlates with a better prognosis, as it often involves less severe cognitive decline and better treatment responses.

questions.text: In the psychiatry OPD, a male patient aged 40 presents with a concern regarding persistent thoughts. Specifically, he experiences a constant belief that his hands are dirty despite them being clean. Consequently, he feels uneasy and is compelled to repeatedly wash his hands. The condition can be classified as a disorder involving thought processes known as ______.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Possession

  • The patient’s persistent, distressing belief that his hands are dirty, despite them being clean, is suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
  • In OCD, thought possession means that the individual is aware that their obsessive thoughts are irrational or excessive, but they cannot stop them.
  • The patient experiences the thoughts as intrusive and unwanted, yet they still recognise them as coming from within their own mind.

Flow (Option A) refers to the overall continuity or rhythm of thought, which can be disrupted in various ways. In a disorder of flow, there may be issues such as racing thoughts or thought blocks. In the patient's case, there's no mention of the speed or rhythm of thoughts being disturbed.

Form (Option B) of thought refers to the structure or organisation of thoughts. It involves whether the thoughts are logically connected or disjointed. Here, the problem isn't with the logical structure of his thoughts but with the content of his thoughts

Content (Option D) refers to the actual subject of the thought, but it doesn't address the distress and lack of control experienced by the patient.

questions.text: What is the approximate age of a person in whom the medial end of the clavicle is fused and also the sternum is completely fused:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 22-25 years

Explanation:

  • The medial end of the clavicle fuses by 20-22 years. The sternum typically completes its fusion in the late teens to early 20s, often around 18 to 25 years. Since both the medial end of the clavicle and the sternum (with fusion of sternebrae) are fully fused by the early 20s, the person is typically between 22-25 years old.

Bone

Centers of Ossification

Age of Appearance

Age of Fusion

Sternum

Manubrium

5th-month IUL

60–70 years (manubrio-sternal joint)

1st sternebrae

5th-month IUL

14-25 years (from below upwards; 3rd and 4th-15 years; 2nd and 3rd-20 years; 1st and 2nd-25 years)

2nd and 3rd sternebrae

7th-month IUL

4th sternebrae

10th-month IUL

Xiphisternum

3rd year postnatal

40-45 years (with body)

Clavicle

Medial end

5th-7th week IUL (1st Ossification centre overall to appear in fetus)

20-22 years

Scapula

Coracoid base

14-17 years

Acromion process

17-18 years

Incorrect Options:

<18 years (Option A) is incorrect because both bones are still in the process of fusion and maturation before 18.

18-22 years (Option B) is too early, as fusion would not be complete yet.

>25 years (Option D is incorrect because both bones would have already fused by that age, making this option too late.

questions.text: During an examination of a woman in labor, a midwife observes a prolapsed cord. What is the immediate next step in managing this situation?

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Put her in Trendelenberg position

Explanation:

  • The Trendelenburg position (lying on the back with legs elevated higher than the head) would cause gravity to shift the fetus upwards into the uterine cavity, away from the prolapsed cord allowing pressure to be relieved. This would be the best immediate next action to be done by the midwife.

 

In case of a prolapsed cord, the healthcare provider should be informed immediately, and the woman should be taken to the operating theatre (OT) for an emergency cesarean section (Option B). This is to ensure a quick delivery and avoid further compression of the cord. A prolapsed umbilical cord is a medical emergency that occurs when the umbilical cord slips down into the birth canal ahead of the baby. This can potentially cut off the baby's oxygen supply, and immediate action is required. In the above scenario mentioned in the question, the next best management would be the change in position.

Attempting to push the cord back inside the vagina (Option A) can compress it further, leading to decreased blood flow to the baby. This should not be done.

While it's important to know the fetal presentation (Option D), in the case of a prolapsed cord, the priority is to inform the doctor and initiate immediate management, which usually involves a cesarean section to deliver the baby promptly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of a woman in labour with a planned vaginal breech delivery is incorrect?

choices.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

Explanation:

  • While a breech presentation (where the baby is positioned bottom-first instead of head-first) does increase the complexity and potential risks associated with vaginal delivery, it is not an absolute contraindication for normal vaginal delivery. In some cases, a breech presentation may be diagnosed for the first time during labor, and a skilled obstetrician may decide that a vaginal breech delivery can still be safely attempted.

 

Breech deliveries should indeed be performed in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available, as complications can arise during labor. (Option B ruled out)

Continuous fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring is essential during breech delivery (Option C ruled out) due to the increased risk of fetal distress, ensuring the well-being of the baby.

A vaginal breech delivery must be managed by a skilled obstetrician (Option D ruled out)with specialized training, as breech deliveries require careful handling to prevent injury to the baby and mother.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Marbling

Explanation:

  • The branching pattern along the blood vessels is typical of marbling, which occurs due to bacterial decomposition of hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin. This phenomenon usually appears 24 hours after death.

Marbling

Definition

Refers to a characteristic pattern in the skin caused by decomposition.

Mechanism

After death, bacteria spread through blood vessels, decomposing hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin, which causes greenish or reddish-brown staining of the vessel walls.

Pattern

Marbled pattern follows a linear branching pattern, resembling tree branches, which initially appears red and later transitions to a greenish hue.

Onset and Timing
  • Begins to develop 24 hours after death.
  • Becomes prominent by 36-48 hours.

Color Changes Over Time

Skin’s reddish-green marbling may turn dark green or nearly black within 3 to 4 days.

Areas of Marbling

Shoulders, roots of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest, and neck.

Medicolegal Importance

Helps in determining the time since death

Image

Postmortem lividity (Option A) typically appears as a uniform discoloration rather than a distinct branching pattern as seen in marbling, making it less relevant in this scenario.

Filigree burns (Option C) are characterized by superficial, irregular markings resulting from electrical discharge that develop within minutes to an hour. In contrast, marbling involves the bacterial decomposition of hemoglobin, creating a distinct branching pattern in the skin, which does not occur immediately and is not indicative of electrical injury.

Subcutaneous emphysema (Option D) occurs when air enters the tissues under the skin, usually from trauma or puncture of the lungs, creating a crackling sensation under the skin.

questions.text: Under which doctrine is the doctor not responsible when a patient with life-threatening injuries arrives at the casualty without time for consent and the doctor initiates life-saving procedures with the utmost care, but unfortunately, the patient still succumbs to death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Doctrine of extended consent

Explanation:

 

The Doctrine of Anticipation applies in emergency situations where:

  • A patient is unconscious or unable to give consent

  • No time is available to obtain informed consent from relatives or legal guardians

  • Immediate medical intervention is necessary to prevent death or serious harm

Under this doctrine, the doctor is legally and ethically justified in initiating life-saving procedures without formal consent, provided the action is in good faith and with due care and skill.

 

Res ipsa loquitur (Option A): Latin for "the thing speaks for itself." This doctrine is used in tort law to infer negligence when the injury wouldn't normally occur without negligence (e.g., surgical instrument left in body). Not applicable here, as the doctor acted carefully and responsibly.

Doctrine of extended consent (Option C):
Applies when a patient consents to a procedure and a related, unforeseen procedure is discovered during the operation and performed. Not relevant in emergency life-saving without prior consent.

Doctrine of conjugated consent (Option D): Not a recognised legal doctrine in medical jurisprudence. Possibly a distractor.

questions.text: The maternal mortality ratio is defined as?

choices.text: Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group
Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births.

  • Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births: The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. It is an important indicator of the quality of healthcare and maternal health in a population.

Key maternal and child health indicators:

Indicator

Definition

Formula

Significance

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

Number of maternal deaths ×100,000

—--------------------------------------

​Number of live births

Indicator of maternal health and the quality of maternal healthcare services.

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR)

Number of infant deaths (under 1 year) per 1,000 live births

​Number of infant deaths ×1,000

—-----------------------------------

Number of live births

Reflects the overall health of infants, healthcare quality, and living conditions.

Under-5 Mortality Rate (U5MR)

Probability of a child dying before age 5 per 1,000 live births

Number of under-5 deaths​ ×1,000

—------------------------------------

Number of live births

Reflects child health and effectiveness of health interventions from birth to age 5.

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR)

Number of deaths of infants aged 0-28 days per 1,000 live births

Number of neonatal deaths​ ×1,000

—-----------------------------------

Number of live births

Measures the health of newborns and effectiveness of neonatal care and interventions.

Child Mortality Rate (CMR)

Number of deaths in children aged 1-4 per 1,000 children in this age group

Number of deaths in children aged 1-4​ ×1,000

—------------------------------------------

Total number of children aged 1-4

Reflects mortality due to preventable causes in children aged 1-4 years, indicating health and nutrition status.

Stillbirth Rate (SBR)

Number of stillbirths per 1,000 live births and stillbirths

Number of stillbirths​ ×1,000

—------------------------------------------

Number of live births + stillbirths

Reflects the quality of prenatal care and the healthcare system’s ability to prevent fetal deaths.

Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (CPR)

Percentage of women of reproductive age using contraception

Number of women using contraception ​×100

—----------------------------------------

Total number of women of reproductive age

Indicates access to and usage of family planning, helping reduce maternal and child mortality.

Total Fertility Rate (TFR)

Average number of children a woman would have over her lifetime

Sum of age-specific fertility rates

Reflects population growth and reproductive health patterns.

Life Expectancy at Birth

Average number of years a newborn is expected to live

N/A

Reflects the overall health and quality of life in a population.

Maternal Deaths per 10,000 live births (Option A): This is incorrect. The maternal mortality ratio is typically measured per 100,000 live births, not 10,000.

Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group (Option C): This is incorrect. The maternal mortality ratio is not calculated based on the number of women in the reproductive age group, but rather on live births.

Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group (Option D): This is incorrect. While this measure might seem relevant, it is not the standard definition of maternal mortality ratio. The proper denominator for maternal mortality is live births, not the reproductive age group population.

questions.text: Identify the grip shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lateral grip

Explanation:

  • The lateral grip is a technique used during labor to assess the descent and rotation of the fetal head. It involves placing the hands on either side of the fetal head to feel for specific movements and changes in position. This grip allows the healthcare provider to monitor the progress of labor and ensure that the baby is moving through the birth canal in the appropriate manner.
  • By placing the hands on either side of the fetal head, the healthcare provider can feel for the movement of the head as it descends and rotates during contractions. The lateral grip helps assess the position of the fetal head in relation to the pelvis and the progress of labor.
  • During labor, the fetal head should gradually descend and rotate to align with the birth canal. The lateral grip allows the healthcare provider to detect any deviations or abnormalities in this process, such as malpositioning or inadequate descent. This information helps guide interventions or decision-making regarding the management of labor.
     

The Pawlik's grip (Option A) aids in confirming the fetal presentation. The examiner uses their thumb and fingers to grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a mobile mass, typically the head, will be felt. Differentiating between the head and breech is similar to the first maneuver.

The Pelvic grip (Option C) helps assess the degree of fetal descent. With the examiner facing the mother's feet, the fingertips of both hands are placed on either side of the presenting part. By exerting inward pressure and then sliding caudally along the pelvic inlet, the examiner can often differentiate between the head, which may be engaged in the pelvis, and the anterior shoulder or the space created by the fetal neck.

Fundal grip (Option D) is a technique used to assess uterine contractions during labor. It involves placing the hands on the upper part (fundus) of the uterus to feel the intensity, frequency, and duration of contractions. Since the image does not correspond to a fundal grip.

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes which of the following:

choices.text: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour

Explanation:

Modified Robson's classification is a system used to categorize and compare cesarean section rates in different groups of women undergoing childbirth.

Class 1 specifically refers to nulliparous women (those who have not previously given birth) with a singleton pregnancy (one fetus) in a cephalic presentation (head-first) (Option A, C, D ruled out) and undergoing spontaneous labor.

This classification helps in analyzing and comparing cesarean section rates within similar groups of women, aiding in quality improvement initiatives and research.

questions.text: Which of the following does not require precautions for airborne transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Herpes Zoster:

Herpes Zoster (shingles) typically does not require airborne precautions unless it is disseminated (spreading across multiple dermatomes or in an immunocompromised host). In its localized form, transmission occurs through direct contact with the fluid from the lesions, so standard precautions are sufficient.

Airborne precautions are required for diseases transmitted via fine respiratory droplets that remain suspended in the air for long periods. These diseases include:

  1. Tuberculosis (Option A): Airborne transmission; precautions are mandatory.
  2. Measles (Option C): Highly contagious and transmitted through airborne droplets; precautions are necessary.
  3. Chickenpox (Varicella) (Option D): Airborne and contact transmission; precautions are required.

questions.text:
As a medical officer, what actions should you take when a 14-year-old girl accompanied by her mother presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of penovaginal penetration by a neighbor, with consent given by the girl? The girl expresses her refusal to undergo an examination.

1. Document informed refusal

2. Do not inform the police

3. Counsel the mother and daughter

4. Examine with necessary force

5. Inform the police
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 5 are true

Explanation:

  • Document informed refusal (True):
    • It is important to document that the 14-year-old girl has expressed her informed refusal for an examination. This ensures that the healthcare professional has made her aware of the medical and legal consequences of her decision, while respecting her autonomy.
  • Do not inform the police (False):
    • Regardless of the girl's consent, sexual activity with a minor (<18 years old) is considered statutory rape. The law mandates that such incidents be reported to the police immediately to ensure the minor's protection.
  • Counsel the mother and daughter (True):
    • The healthcare professional should counsel both on the legal implications, reporting importance, and emotional impact.
  • Examine with necessary force (False):
    • An examination should not be forced if the patient refuses. It should proceed only with consent or legal authority.
  • Inform the police (True): The healthcare professional is legally obligated to inform the police in cases of statutory rape to ensure legal protection for the minor.

 

Procedures in a Rape Victim:

  • Initial Steps:
    • The police should advise the survivor not to bathe or change clothes to preserve evidence.
    • The scene of the offense may be visited if necessary.
    • The medical officer must ensure the survivor is treated with sensitivity and in an environment of trust, particularly when the survivor is from a marginalized group.
  • Examination Procedure:
    • A police requisition is required, except when the victim approaches the doctor directly.
    • Informed consent must be obtained for the examination and evidence collection. The survivor has the right to refuse parts of the examination, but this refusal should be documented.
    • Consent must be signed by the survivor (if ≥12 years old) or their guardian (if <12 years old).
    • The survivor can refuse to report to the police, but the doctor is still required to inform them about the incident.
  • Examining Process:
    • The victim should be identified, and a female doctor or attendant should ideally conduct the examination, or a female presence should be maintained.
    • The examination should be carried out promptly to prevent loss of evidence.
    • Statements from the victim and accompanying persons should be recorded separately, especially if the abuser is present.
    • Special care should be given to transgender or intersex individuals, respecting their preferences for examination.
  • Additional Considerations:
    • Survivors with disabilities or from vulnerable groups (like sex workers) should be handled with particular care and their consent for examination should be respected.
    • Past sexual encounters should not be documented unless relevant to the current incident.
    • The Supreme Court recognizes that non-consensual intercourse with sex workers constitutes rape.

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 880KCal

Explanation:

  • To calculate the number of calories delivered in the TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) bag, we need to know the caloric value of each macronutrient.

The caloric values per gram for each macronutrient are as follows:

  • Glucose: 4 calories per gram
  • Amino acids: 4 calories per gram
  • Lipids (fats): 9 calories per gram

 

Now let's calculate the calories for each component of the TPN bag:

  • Glucose: 100g of glucose * 4 calories/gram = 400 calories.
  • Amino acids: 30g of amino acids * 4 calories/gram = 120 calories.
  • Lipids: 40g of lipids * 9 calories/gram = 360 calories.

 

Now, let's add up the calories from each component: 400 calories (glucose) + 120 calories (amino acids) + 360 calories (lipids) = 880 calories

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not included in the RBSK screening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma

  • The RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram) screening program is a government initiative in India aimed at identifying and providing early intervention for various health conditions in children up to the age of 18 years.
  • The diseases screened under RBSK include conditions like congenital cataract, retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), and Vitamin A deficiency.
  • However, congenital glaucoma is not part of the routine screening under RBSK.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK):

Aspect

Details

Program

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Launched

2013 under the National Health Mission

Objective

Improve child health through early identification, screening, and management of health conditions among children aged 0 to 18 years

Target Conditions (4Ds)

Defects at Birth: Examples include cleft lip/palate, Down syndrome

Diseases: Examples include rheumatic heart disease

Deficiencies: Examples include anemia, Vitamin A deficiency

Developmental Delays including Disabilities

Screening Teams

Mobile health teams comprising a medical officer, staff nurse, and pharmacist

Screening Locations

Schools, Anganwadi centers, and homes

Referral System

District Early Intervention Centers (DEICs) for further management

Significance

Improves early detection and management of child health issues, reducing morbidity and enhancing quality of life

Congenital cataract (Option A): This condition is included in the RBSK screening, as it is an important cause of preventable blindness in children.

Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) (Option C): ROP is included in the screening, as it is a major cause of visual impairment in premature infants.

Vitamin A deficiency (Option D): This is also part of the RBSK screening, as it can lead to blindness and other health complications.

questions.text: Ammonia in the brain is detoxified to form
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glutamine

Explanation:

  • Ammonia in Brian is detoxified to form Glutamine.
  • Glutamine synthetase in astrocytes converts glutamate and ammonia to glutamine, effectively detoxifying ammonia in the brain.

Ammonia Management in Neurons:

  • Ammonia can be neurotoxic if accumulated.

Glutamine Synthesis:

  • Produced in neurons as a byproduct of amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter turnover.
  • Ammonia reacts with α-ketoglutarate and NADH to form glutamate, catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase.

α-ketoglutarate + NH3​ ​+ NADH → Glutamate + NAD+ + H2​O

  • Glutamate is converted to glutamine by glutamine synthetase, adding another ammonia molecule. Glutamine synthetase is predominantly found in astrocytes.

Glutamate + NH3​ + ATP → Glutamine + ADP + Pi

  • This conversion reduces ammonia toxicity by storing it in a non-toxic form.

 

The fate of glutamine:

Release into the Bloodstream:

  • Glutamine is released into the extracellular space and enters the bloodstream.
  • This transport helps maintain nitrogen balance and prevents ammonia accumulation.

 

Transport to the Liver:

  • Glutamine carries ammonia from the brain to the liver, where it is deaminated to release ammonia.
  • Ammonia enters the urea cycle in the liver for detoxification.

 

Importance of Glutamine in Neuronal Health:

  • Acts as a non-toxic ammonia carrier, preventing neurotoxicity.
  • Serves as a precursor for neurotransmitters like GABA, maintaining neurotransmitter balance.

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in freshwater drowning?

A. Haemodilution

B. Hypokalemia

C. Hyponatremia

D. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A, C & D

Explanation:

Features

Freshwater Drowning

Seawater Drowning

Pathophysiology
  • Haemodilution (Statement A): Inhalation increases blood volume by 50%, causing anemia, hemolysis, and myocardial hypoxia.
  • Electrolyte Changes: Marked hyponatremia (Statement C) and hyperkalemia (Statement B ruled out); calcium decrease leads to arrhythmias. (Statement D)
  • Surfactant Dysfunction: Freshwater denatures the surfactant which causes alveolar collapse and pulmonary oedema.
  • Cardiac Load: Increased pulmonary oedema and electrolyte imbalances decrease cardiac output and cause hypotension.
  • Haemoconcentration: High salinity (≥3% NaCl) draws water into the lungs, causing severe pulmonary oedema and elevated plasma sodium.
  • Electrolyte Changes: Increased blood viscosity leads to bradycardia and myocardial failure; altered potassium and sodium levels(hypernatremia)
  • Red Cell Changes: Crenation of red blood cells impairs oxygen transport.
  • Myocardial Anoxia: Asphyxia from pulmonary oedema and cardiac stress results in hypoxia and potential arrest.

Lung characteristics
  • Size: Ballooned but light; pale pink colour; emphysematous consistency.
  • Shape after Removal: Retained, no collapse; crepitus with little froth and no fluid.
  • Size: Ballooned and heavy; purplish or bluish colour; soft, jelly-like consistency.
  • Shape after Removal: Flattened; no crepitus; copious fluid and froth.

Fatal period
  • Death typically occurs within 4-5 minutes
  • Death may take 8-10 minutes.

questions.text: What is the serum level of tetanus antitoxin required for clinical protection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - >0.01 IU/ml.

  • Tetanus antitoxin levels in the serum indicate immunity against tetanus. A protective level of tetanus antitoxin is defined as ≥0.01 IU/ml, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). This level is sufficient to neutralize the tetanus toxin and provide clinical protection.

questions.text: Glucose is stored in the form of glycogen because

choices.text: It can be stored at multiple organs
It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is compact

Explanation:

  • Glycogen is a polysaccharide composed of many glucose molecules linked together through alpha-1,4-glycosidic bonds and branched with alpha-1,6-glycosidic bonds.
  • By storing glucose as glycogen, the body can efficiently pack a large amount of glucose molecules into a compact and readily available form.
  • This compact storage allows for efficient storage of glucose within cells, especially in tissues such as the liver and muscles, where glycogen serves as a reserve energy source.

 

It has multiple reducing ends (Option B): While it is true that glycogen has multiple reducing ends due to its branched structure, this is not the primary reason why glucose is stored as glycogen.

It can be stored at multiple organs (Option C): Although glycogen can be stored in multiple organs, such as the liver and muscles, this is not the main reason why glucose is stored as glycogen.

It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed (Option D): The storage capacity of glycogen varies depending on the individual and their glycogen reserves.

questions.text: The enzyme that is not used in cholesterol synthesis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HMG CoA lyase

Explanation:

HMG CoA lyase:

  • Cholesterol synthesis involves several key enzymes, but HMG CoA lyase is not one of them.
  • HMG CoA lyase: This enzyme is involved in ketogenesis, where it converts HMG CoA to acetoacetate (a ketone body), and it is not involved in the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway.

Enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis:

  • Thiolase : This enzyme catalyzes the first step in cholesterol synthesis, where two acetyl-CoA molecules are combined to form acetoacetyl-CoA.
  • HMG CoA synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the next step, combining acetoacetyl-CoA with another acetyl-CoA to form HMG CoA (3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA).
  • HMG CoA reductase: This is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis. It converts HMG CoA to mevalonate, a crucial step in the pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following bags are used for disposing of latex gloves after they have been used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Red

  • Used latex gloves are classified as infectious biomedical waste and should be disposed of in red bags, as per the Biomedical Waste Management Rules, 2016.

Color-Coded Waste Disposal System:

  1. Red Bag:
    • Used for contaminated items like:
      • Latex gloves
      • IV tubes, catheters, syringes (without needles)
      • Disposable PPE
    • These items are sent for autoclaving or shredding followed by recycling.
  2. Yellow Bag: (Option A ruled out)
    • Used for waste requiring incineration, such as:
      • Anatomical waste
      • Soiled dressings, bandages
      • Pathological waste (e.g., human tissues)
  3. Blue Bag: (Option C ruled out)
    • Used for glassware and sharp metal objects, such as:
      • Broken ampoules
      • Vials
      • Metallic implants
  4. Transparent Bag: (Option D ruled out)
    • Typically used for general waste like paper, food, or non-infectious material.

questions.text: Glasgow coma scale is a type of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Ordinal scale data

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess the level of consciousness in a patient. It assigns scores based on three components:

  1. Eye opening (1 to 4)
  2. Verbal response (1 to 5)
  3. Motor response (1 to 6)

The total score ranges from 3 to 15, with higher scores indicating better neurological function.

Data Type:

  • The GCS is considered ordinal scale data because:
    • The scores indicate an order or rank (e.g., a score of 4 is better than 3 in motor response).
    • However, the difference between scores (e.g., between 3 and 4) does not necessarily represent an equal increment in consciousness level, which makes it ordinal rather than interval or ratio.

Nominal scale data (Option A): Used for categorization without any order (e.g., blood groups). GCS has an inherent ranking, so it is not nominal.

Alphanumerical data (Option C): Refers to data containing letters and numbers. GCS consists only of numerical scores.

Interval scale data (Option D): Involves ordered data with equal intervals between values (e.g., temperature in Celsius). GCS does not have equal intervals between scores, so it is not interval scale data.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fissured

Explanation:

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture) (Option C)

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture) (Option A ruled out)
  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents).
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

Depressed Fracture

(Option B ruled out)

Comminuted Fracture

(Option D ruled out)

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

Depressed fracture

Comminuted fracture

Gutter fracture

questions.text: A new drug combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy for metastatic melanoma was prescribed by a radiotherapist. It prolongs survival. Which of the following is true in this situation?

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases:

  • Incidence: Refers to the number of new cases of a disease occurring in a specific population during a defined time period.
  • Prevalence: Refers to the total number of cases (both new and existing) in a specific population at a given time.

Impact of Prolonging Survival on Incidence and Prevalence:

  1. Incidence:
    • The number of new cases of metastatic melanoma is not affected by the treatment. Therefore, the incidence remains the same.
  2. Prevalence:
    • Prolonging survival means patients live longer with the disease, resulting in an increase in the total number of cases at any given time. Hence, the prevalence increases.

Incidence increases and prevalence reduces (Option A): This is incorrect because prolonging survival does not increase the number of new cases (incidence), and prevalence cannot reduce when survival increases.

Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same (Option B): The new treatment does not affect the occurrence of new cases (incidence), and prolonging survival would increase, not stabilize, prevalence.

Incidence reduces and prevalence increases (Option D): The treatment affects survival, not the occurrence of new cases, so the incidence remains unchanged.

questions.text: Which of the following populations is not included in the HIV sentinel surveillance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - STD clinic attendees.

  • HIV Sentinel Surveillance (HSS) is designed to track the trends of HIV prevalence in different population groups.
  • However, STD clinic attendees are not specifically included in the sentinel surveillance system in most cases.
  • This is because these individuals are already considered a part of the high-risk population, and their data may overlap with other more defined high-risk groups, such as female sex workers and men who have sex with men.

HIV Sentinel Surveillance (HSS):

Category

Details

Objective

Monitor trends in HIV prevalence, guide public health interventions, and identify high-risk populations.

Sentinel Sites

Specific locations for surveillance, including antenatal clinics, STD clinics, and high-risk community settings.

Populations Included

Antenatal Women: To estimate HIV prevalence in the general population.

High-Risk Groups: Female sex workers (FSWs), men who have sex with men (MSM), injecting drug users (IDUs).

Bridge Populations: Truck drivers, single male migrants.

Data Collected

HIV Prevalence: Percentage of individuals in the group who are HIV-positive.

Demographic Information: Age, gender, occupation, etc.

Risk Behavior: Sexual behavior, drug use, and other HIV transmission risk factors.

Key Features

Regular blood sample collection.

HIV testing conducted in sentinel sites.

Exclusions

STD clinic attendees may not be included as their data overlaps with other high-risk groups.

Importance

Tracks HIV trends over time.

Guides the allocation of resources.

Helps design targeted prevention programs for at-risk populations.

Single male migrants (Option A): They are often at higher risk due to mobility and exposure to multiple sexual partners.

Truck drivers (Option B): A high-risk group due to frequent travel and potential for high-risk sexual behavior.

Antenatal women (Option D): Provide important data on the general population and mother-to-child transmission.

questions.text: Identify the seeds shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nigella sativa

Explanation:

  • Nigella sativa (black seed) is a medicinal plant from the Ranunculaceae family, widely used in traditional medicines like Unani, Ayurveda, and Tibb-e-Nabwi.
  • These are small, black, angular seeds commonly known as black cumin or kalonji, used in cooking and traditional medicine.
  • Therapeutic Uses: It has various health benefits, including anti-hypertensive, anti-diabetic, anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and hepatoprotective properties.
  • Key Component: The active compound, thymoquinone, in the oil and seeds, is responsible for most of its therapeutic effects.
  • Common Uses: It is used to treat conditions like bronchitis, asthma, diarrhea, rheumatism, and skin disorders, and also as a digestive aid, appetite stimulant, and immune booster.
  • Cultural Significance: Considered a "miracle herb," it is $highly regarded in Islamic medicine, where it is believed to cure all diseases except death.

Incorrect Options:

Tropicana canna (Option A): The seeds are large, spherical, and hard, typically used as beads or ornaments. They do not resemble the smaller, black, and shiny seeds of Nigella sativa.

Datura seeds (Option C): Datura seeds are flat, kidney-shaped, and brownish-yellow, distinct from the black seeds of Nigella sativa.

Opium seeds (Option D): Also known as poppy seeds, they are small, round, and greyish-blue, distinctly different in color and texture from Nigella sativa seeds.

questions.text: What is the most effective quantitative method for examining previous research studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Meta-analysis

Meta-analysis is considered the most effective quantitative method for examining previous research studies. It involves the statistical combination of results from multiple studies to identify patterns, improve precision, and estimate the overall effect size of a given intervention or exposure.

  1. Meta-analysis combines data from various studies, which increases the statistical power and allows for a more comprehensive conclusion than individual studies alone.
  2. It provides a quantitative summary of the effects, allowing for a clearer understanding of the consistency and strength of findings across different populations or settings.
  3. Systematic reviews, which often precede meta-analysis, are a rigorous method of synthesizing existing research, but meta-analysis takes it a step further by statistically integrating results.

Cohort Study (Option A): This is an observational study design used to follow groups of people over time but is not a method for examining previous research studies.

Systematic Review (Option B): A systematic review is a comprehensive summary of existing research, but it does not necessarily include statistical analysis. It organizes and assesses the quality of existing studies.

RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial) (Option D): An RCT is a primary research design for evaluating interventions but does not deal with summarizing previous research studies.

questions.text: Which of the following defines rape?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 375 IPC

Explanation:

Rape definition and conditions

Section 375 IPC (BNS 63) defines rape:

a) Penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or

b) Inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or

c) Manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of body of such woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or

d) Applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, urethra of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person, under the circumstances falling under any of the following seven descriptions:

  1. Against her will
  2. Without her consent
  3. With her consent, only because she or someone she cares about is threatened with harm or death.
  4. With her consent, she mistakenly believes the man is her lawful husband when the man knows that he is not her husband.
  5. With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, she cannot understand the nature or consequences due to intoxication, mental incapacity, or being drugged.
  6. With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.
  7. When she is unable to communicate consent.

Exceptions:

  • A medical procedure or intervention shall not constitute rape.
  • Sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under eighteen years of age, is not rape.

Note: Even if a girl gives consent below 18 years, it is known as statutory rape.

Incorrect Options:

376 IPC (Option B) prescribes the punishment for rape. It outlines the penalties for committing rape, including rigorous imprisonment and fines, with more severe punishments for aggravated circumstances.

377 IPC (Option C) pertains to unnatural offenses, criminalizing sexual acts “against the order of nature” (a historically controversial provision, partially decriminalized for consensual same-sex relations in 2018).

498(A) IPC (Option D) addresses cruelty by husband or relatives of the husband towards a woman. This includes harassment, physical abuse, and mental torture, often related to dowry demands.

questions.text: Which data set provides the most comprehensive explanation for the variation between the highest and lowest values?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Range

The range is the simplest measure of variation in a dataset. It is calculated by subtracting the lowest value from the highest value, providing a direct measure of the spread or dispersion of the data.

  • Range = Highest value - Lowest value
  • It gives a clear indication of the overall spread of data from the minimum to the maximum.

Variance (Option A): Variance measures the average squared deviation from the mean. While it indicates the spread of data, it does not directly focus on the highest and lowest values.

Coefficient of Variation (Option B): The coefficient of variation is the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean and expresses the variability relative to the mean. It’s useful for comparing relative variability but doesn't focus on the highest and lowest values.

Interquartile Range (IQR) (Option D): The IQR measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data (between the 25th and 75th percentiles). While it indicates the dispersion of the central portion of the data, it does not address the variation between the highest and lowest values as directly as the range.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning liquid-based cytology?

choices.text: Study of fluid in the tumor microenvironment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Urine specimen is used

Explanation:

  • Liquid-based cytology is often used to collect specimens, including urine, and study cells for various diagnostic purposes.

Liquid-based cytology:

  • It is a technique to collect and prepare cell samples for microscopic analysis.
  • It involves gathering cells from various body fluids, such as cervical or vaginal fluids, respiratory secretions, or urine, depending on the diagnostic goal.
  • This method is commonly used for cervical cancer screening. Cells collected from the cervix with a brush or spatula are suspended in a preservative solution. This suspension is used to prepare slides for cytological examination to detect abnormalities or disease.
  • Advantages of Liquid-Based Cytology (LBC):
    • Improved slide preparation: LBC creates a thin-layer or monolayer slide preparation, providing better quality and clarity than conventional Papanicolaou (Pap) smears.
    • Enhanced cell preservation: The collection fluid used in LBC fixes, homogenizes, and rinses the cells, ensuring better preservation for microscopic examination.
    • Reduced sample contamination: The homogenization process minimizes the presence of non-representative material, such as blood or mucus, leading to a more accurate analysis of the collected cells.
    • Increased diagnostic accuracy: With improved sample quality, LBC enhances the sensitivity and specificity of cervical cancer screening, allowing for more reliable detection of abnormalities.
  • Disadvantage:
    • Although cervical cytological screening has proven effective in reducing the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer, the conventional Pap test is less sensitive than commonly thought. The false-negative rate of the conventional Pap test has been reported to reach as high as 50%.

questions.text: A woman who had undergone total knee replacement surgery comes back with complaints of knee pain and loosening of implants. The following histopathological slide was obtained, showing foreign body giant cells and the appearance highlighted in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metallosis

Explanation:

  • Metallosis refers to the accumulation of metal debris in tissues commonly associated with wear and corrosion of metal implants, such as those used in joint replacements. This causes inflammation, foreign body giant cells, and metallic debris, visible on histopathology.

Metallosis:

  • Definition: Aseptic fibrosis, local necrosis, and prosthetic loosening due to metal wear and corrosion in metal-on-metal (MoM) implants.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Metallic debris (cobalt, chromium, titanium) triggers an inflammatory response, leading to foreign body giant cell reaction, cytokine release, and tissue necrosis.
    • Systemic metal ion absorption may cause neuropathy, cardiomyopathy, and thyroid dysfunction.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Local: Chronic pain, swelling, pseudotumors, skin discolouration.
    • Systemic: Neurological, cardiac, and endocrine toxicity.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum cobalt and chromium levels.
    • MARS MRI (Metal Artifact Reduction Sequence) for pseudotumors.
    • Histopathology: Pigmented macrophages, metal debris, necrosis.
  • Management
    • Regular monitoring of metal ion levels and symptoms.
    • Revision surgery with non-metallic implants in symptomatic cases.

Incorrect Options:

Ochronosis (Option A): A rare condition often associated with alkaptonuria, characterized by dark pigmentation in cartilage but not related to metal debris from implants.

Malignant melanoma (Option C) is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. It typically presents as a pigmented skin lesion and does not cause the formation of foreign body giant cells or be associated with metal debris from joint replacements.

Rosai-Dorfman disease (Option D) is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of histiocytes (a type of white blood cell) in various organs, leading to lymphadenopathy and other systemic symptoms. It is not related to the inflammatory response caused by metal debris in metallosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a constituent of the Papanicolaou stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Eosin B

Explanation:

  • Eosin B is not a constituent of the Papanicolaou stain. Eosin is a different type of stain typically used for general histology to highlight cytoplasm in tissues, but it is not used in the Papanicolaou (Pap) stain.
  • The Papanicolaou (Pap) stain is a widely used technique for examining cells from the cervix to screen for cervical cancer and other abnormalities. It uses a combination of multiple dyes to differentiate cellular components:
    • Hematoxylin - Stains the cell nuclei, allowing for clear visualization of nuclear structure.
    • Orange G - Stains keratinized cells orange, highlighting squamous cells.
    • Eosin A - Second counterstain & a polychrome mixture of Eosin Y and Light Green (stains cytoplasm and helps differentiate between various cell types).

questions.text: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Methanol

Explanation:

Methanol is not a crosslinking fixative. It is a dehydrant coagulant fixative.

Fixatives are chemicals that preserve biological tissues by stabilizing cellular structures and preventing decay or degradation. The goal is to maintain the tissue in a life-like state as much as possible for microscopic examination.

  • Fixation helps maintain the tissue's integrity by preventing autolysis (self-digestion) and putrefaction (bacterial decay).
  • Crosslinking Fixatives: These fixatives work by forming covalent bonds between the proteins and other cellular structures, effectively "locking" them in place. This preserves the tissue’s structural integrity.
    • Formaldehyde (Option B): Most commonly used in the form of 10% neutral-buffered formalin.
    • Glutaraldehyde (Option A): Often used for electron microscopy due to its ability to preserve fine cellular structures.
    • Osmium tetroxide (Option D): Used primarily for electron microscopy, particularly for preserving lipids and membranes.
  • Precipitating Fixatives: These work by precipitating proteins and other cellular components, which makes them less soluble and helps preserve their structure.
    • Methanol
    • Ethanol
  • Additive Fixatives: They chemically bind to tissue components, such as proteins or nucleic acids, and stabilize them. They are typically more gentle and produce better preservation of ultrastructure.
    • Formaldehyde
    • Glutaraldehyde
  • Non-Additive Fixatives:
    • Alcohol
    • Acetone

questions.text: Isotype switching is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Activated B cells

Explanation:

  • Isotype switching, also known as class switching, occurs in activated B cells. This process allows B cells to produce different classes of antibodies (e.g., IgM, IgG, IgA, IgE) in response to specific signals, such as cytokines from helper T cells, during an immune response.

  • Isotype switching, also referred to as class switching or immunoglobulin class switch recombination (CSR), is a process that takes place in activated B cells.
  • During this process, B cells change the class of antibodies they produce, transitioning from IgM to other isotypes such as IgG, IgA, or IgE.
  • Isotype switching enables B cells to generate antibodies with diverse effector functions while preserving the antigen-binding specificity of the original antibody.

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells


Defect in class switching - Hyper IgM Syndrome, caused by defects in CD40L (X-linked) or CD40/AID/UNG (autosomal recessive), leads to high IgM with low IgG, IgA, and IgE, causing recurrent infections. Diagnosis involves immunoglobulin levels and genetic testing, with treatment including IVIG and prophylactic antibiotics.

questions.text: What type of urinary casts would you expect in a patient diagnosed with Fabry’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Maltese cross cast

Explanation:

  • Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by alpha-galactosidase A deficiency, leading to globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) accumulation in tissues, including the kidneys.
  • A characteristic finding in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also referred to as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts. These casts form when Gb3 precipitates within the renal tubules and appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when observed under polarized light.
